**I. INTRODUCTION**
-------------------

1.

This case concerns a dispute submitted to the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes ("**ICSID**" or the "**Centre**") under the Energy Charter Treaty ("**ECT**"), which entered into force on April 16, 1998, with respect to the Federal Republic of Germany and the Kingdom of Spain, and the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States, which entered into force on October 14, 1966 (the "**ICSID Convention**").

2.

The dispute relates to measures adopted by the Respondent, which modified the regulatory and remuneration framework applicable to Concentrated Solar Power ("**CSP**") producers. The Claimant argues that these measures adversely affected its investment in Arenales Solar PS, S.L. ("**Arenales Solar**"), a Spanish company that owns a solar thermal power plant project with molten salt storage, located in the municipality of Morón de la Frontera, Seville (the "**Project**" or "**Arenales Project**").

3.

The Claimant alleges that Spain has breached its obligations under Articles 10(1) and 13 of the ECT. The Claimant asserts that it is entitled to compensation of no less than EUR 79 million for the damages caused to its investment as a result of the ECT violations.

**II. THE PARTIES**
-------------------

4.

The Claimant is STEAG GmbH ("**Steag**"), a company incorporated under German law, with its registered office in Essen.

5.

The Respondent is the Kingdom of Spain ("**Spain**"), a sovereign State and Contracting Party to both the ECT and the ICSID Convention.

6.

Hereinafter, the Claimant and the Respondent shall be collectively referred to as the "**Parties**."

**III. CONSENT TO ARBITRATION**
-------------------------------

7.

The Claimant has submitted a claim based on Article 26 of the ECT and the ICSID Convention against the Kingdom of Spain, as detailed in Section IV below. The Respondent is a Contracting Party to both the ECT and the ICSID Convention. The Tribunal finds that both Parties have provided written consent to this arbitration, without prejudice to the Respondent's objections to the Tribunal's jurisdiction.

**IV. PROCEDURAL HISTORY**
--------------------------

8.

On January 9, 2015, the Centre received a Request for Arbitration from Steag against Spain, accompanied by documentary exhibits C-0001 to C-0008 ("**Request for Arbitration**"), in accordance with Article 36 of the ICSID Convention.

9.

On January 21, 2015, the Secretary-General of ICSID registered the Request for Arbitration pursuant to Article 36(3) of the ICSID Convention and notified the Parties of its registration. In the registration notification, the Secretary-General invited the Parties to inform the Centre of any agreed stipulations regarding the number of arbitrators and their method of appointment, in accordance with Rule 7(c) of the Procedural Rules Applicable to the Initiation of ICSID Conciliation and Arbitration Proceedings. Additionally, the Parties were invited to proceed with the constitution of an arbitral tribunal under Articles 37 to 40 of the ICSID Convention.

10.

On June 17, 2015, ICSID informed the Parties that unless they intervened in the proceedings or requested a suspension by July 21, 2015, the Secretary-General would issue an order taking note of the termination of the proceedings pursuant to Rule 45 of the Procedural Rules Applicable to Arbitration Proceedings ("**Arbitration Rules**").

11.

On July 21, 2015, the Claimant appointed Dr. Guido Santiago Tawil as arbitrator, a national of the Argentine Republic,1 and proposed a method to the Respondent regarding the number of arbitrators and their appointment procedure. On the same date, the Centre informed the Parties that, in accordance with the ICSID Convention and the Arbitration Rules, it would not take any action regarding the appointment of Dr. Tawil until the Parties reached an agreement on the number of arbitrators and the method of their appointment.

By letter dated July 31, 2020, Dr. Tawil informed the Parties that he had recently acquired Portuguese nationality in addition to his Argentine nationality.

12.

Through communications dated August 10, September 15, 18, and 24, 2015, the Parties exchanged proposals concerning the number of arbitrators and the appointment procedure. The Parties agreed to constitute the tribunal under Article 37(2)(a) of the ICSID Convention, as follows: the tribunal would be composed of three arbitrators, one appointed by each Party, and the third, who would preside over the tribunal, would be jointly selected by the Parties.

13.

On September 29, 2015, ICSID notified the Parties that Dr. Tawil had accepted his appointment as arbitrator in the proceedings.

14.

On October 23, 2015, the Respondent appointed Prof. Pierre-Marie Dupuy, a national of the French Republic, as arbitrator. On October 27, 2015, ICSID notified the Parties that Prof. Dupuy had accepted his appointment as arbitrator.

15.

On December 30, 2015, the Centre invited the Parties to update it on the status of their discussions regarding the appointment of the President of the Tribunal. On December 31, 2015, the Claimant indicated that the Parties had initiated and wished to continue discussions with a view to reaching an agreement on the appointment of the Presiding Arbitrator.

16.

On May 10, 2016, in the absence of any further updates from the Parties following the Claimant's communication of December 31, [2015,] the Centre invited the Parties to confirm whether they wished to extend the six-month period provided under Rule 45 of the Arbitration Rules.

17.

On June 22, 2016, the Claimant requested that the Chairman of the ICSID Administrative Council proceed with the appointment of the President of the Tribunal, in accordance with Article 38 of the ICSID Convention and Rule 4 of the Arbitration Rules.

18.

On June 23, 2016, ICSID acknowledged receipt of the Claimant's request of June 22, 2016, and informed the Parties that it would initially provide a ballot in order to facilitate the mutual selection of a Presiding Arbitrator. If the ballot process did not result in a mutually agreed selection of one of the proposed candidates, the Chairman of the ICSID Administrative Council would proceed with the appointment of the President of the Tribunal from the ICSID Panel of Arbitrators, in consultation with the Parties.

19.

On August 4, 2016, the Centre provided the Parties with a ballot listing five proposed candidates for the position of President of the Tribunal. On September 5, 2016, each Party submitted its completed ballot to ICSID. On September 6, 2016, the Centre informed the Parties that the ballot process had not resulted in the selection of a mutually agreed candidate.

20.

On September 23, 2016, the Centre informed the Parties that it intended to propose to the Chairman of the ICSID Administrative Council the appointment of Dr. Eduardo Zuleta Jaramillo, a national of the Republic of Colombia, as third arbitrator and President of the Tribunal, and invited the Parties to submit any comments they may have on this proposal by September 29, 2016.

21.

On October 17, 2016, the Centre transmitted to the Parties additional information provided by Dr. Zuleta regarding observations submitted by the Parties on September 29 and 30, 2016. Additionally, ICSID informed the Parties that any further observations regarding this proposal should be submitted no later than October 20, 2016, and that, in the absence of such observations, the Centre would proceed with the proposed appointment.

22.

On October 21, 2016, ICSID informed the Parties that, having received no additional observations regarding the appointment of Dr. Zuleta, the Chairman of the ICSID Administrative Council would proceed with his appointment as President of the Tribunal, in accordance with Article 38 of the ICSID Convention and Rule 4(1) of the Arbitration Rules.

23.

On October 25, 2016, Dr. Zuleta accepted his appointment as President of the Tribunal. On the same date, the Acting Secretary-General of ICSID notified the Parties that the three arbitrators had accepted their respective appointments, that the Tribunal had been constituted, and that the proceedings were deemed to have commenced. Additionally, the Centre informed the Parties that Ms. Ana Constanza Conover Blancas, Legal Counsel at ICSID, would serve as Secretary of the Tribunal.

24.

On December 5, 2016, the Tribunal held its first session with the Parties via teleconference, in accordance with Rule 13(1) of the Arbitration Rules.

25.

On January 10, 2017, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 1, which incorporated the agreements between the Parties on procedural matters and the Tribunal's decisions on disputed issues. Procedural Order No. 1 established, inter alia, that: the applicable ICSID Arbitration Rules would be those in effect as of April 10, 2006; Spanish would be the language of the proceedings; and Washington, D.C. would be the seat of the arbitration. Procedural Order No. 1 also set out the procedural schedule for the present arbitration.

26.

On May 26, 2017, the Claimant submitted its Memorial of Claim, accompanied by: Documentary Exhibits C-0009 to C-0020; Legal Authorities CL-0001 to CL-0068; and the following documents: ***(i)*** Witness Statement of Mr. Joachim Rumstadt, dated May 24, 2017 (submitted in English); ***(ii)*** Witness Statement of Mr. Gregor Timmerhaus, dated May 24, 2017 (submitted in English); ***(iii)*** Witness Statement of Mr. Daniel Ponce de León Pérez, dated May 25, 2017; ***(iv)*** Expert Report by The Brattle Group, titled *"Regulatory Changes in Spanish Legislation on Solar Thermal Power Plants",* dated May 26, 2017, prepared by Dr. José Antonio García and Mr. Richard Caldwell (submitted in English); and (v) Expert Report by The Brattle Group, titled "*Economic Damages Suffered by STEAG*", dated May 26, 2017, prepared by Mr. Richard Caldwell and Dr. José Antonio García (submitted in English).

27.

By communications dated May 31 and June 6, 2017, after receiving observations from the Parties, the Tribunal requested that the Claimant submit Spanish translations of the two witness statements and two expert reports that had been submitted in English with its Memorial of Claim. The Claimant provided these translations on July 11, 2017.

28.

On September 1, 2017, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 2, concerning the number of copies and format of submission for the Parties' written pleadings.

29.

On November 3, 2017, the Respondent submitted its Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, accompanied by: Documentary Exhibits R-0001 to R-0243; Legal Authorities RL-0001 to RL-0089; and Expert Report by Accuracy, titled "*First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim*", dated November 3, 2017, prepared by Mr. Eduard Saura and Mr. Nicolas Barsalou (submitted in English).

30.

On the same date, the Tribunal requested that the Respondent provide a Spanish translation of the expert report, which had been submitted in English with its Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits. The Respondent provided this translation on November 10, 2017.

31.

On December 22, 2017, after exchanges between the Parties and in accordance with the procedural schedule established in Procedural Order No. 1, the Parties submitted their respective document production requests in Redfern schedule format for the Tribunal's decision.

32.

On January 15, 2018, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 3, addressing the Parties' document production requests.

33.

On May 11, 2018, the Claimant submitted its Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, accompanied by: Documentary Exhibits C-0021 to C-0075; Legal Authorities CL-0069 to CL-0128; and The following documents: ***(i)*** Witness Statement of Mr. Daniel Voswinkel, dated May 10, 2018; ***(ii)*** Witness Statement of Mr. Peter Weiß, dated May 11, 2018; ***(iii)*** Expert Report by The Brattle Group, titled "*Reply Report*: *Regulatory Changes in Spanish Legislation on Solar Thermal Power Plants*", dated May 11, 2018, prepared by Dr. José Antonio García and Mr. Richard Caldwell (submitted in English); ***(iv)*** Expert Report by The Brattle Group, titled *"Rebuttal Report: Economic Damages Suffered by STEAG"*, dated May 11, 2018, prepared by Mr. Richard Caldwell and Dr. José Antonio García (submitted in English); and ***(v)*** Expert Report by Enolcon, titled "*Expert Opinion on the Expected Useful Life*", dated May 11, 2018 (submitted in English).

34.

On the same date, the Claimant indicated that it would submit Spanish translations of the documents filed in English with its Reply as soon as possible. The Claimant provided these translations on May 21, 24, and 30, 2018.

35.

On June 27, 2018, the Respondent submitted a *"Request for Inspection of the Arenales CSP (Concentrated Solar Power) Plant by Useful Life and Overcapacity Experts."* In its Request, the Respondent asked the Tribunal to order the Claimant to allow the Respondent's designated experts access to Arenales Plant in order to conduct a technical review of the plant's operation and maintenance.

36.

On July 2, 2018, the Claimant submitted observations on the Respondent's Request of June 27, 2018, accompanied by Documentary Exhibits C-0076 to C-0079.

37.

On July 6 and 9, 2019, the Parties submitted additional observations on the Respondent's Request of June 27, 2018.

38.

On July 10, 2018, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 4, addressing the Respondent's Request of June 27, 2018. In that Order, the Tribunal noted that the Parties had agreed that the Respondent's experts could visit Arenales Plant, and it ruled on the disputed issues concerning the terms and conditions of the visit.

39.

On August 9, 2018, the Respondent submitted its Rejoinder on the Merits and Reply on Jurisdiction, accompanied by: Documentary Exhibits R-0244 to R-0432; Legal Authorities RL-0090 to RL-0136; and the following documents: ***(i)*** Witness Statement of Mr. Carlos Montoya, dated July 26, 2018; ***(ii)*** Expert Report by Accuracy, titled "*Second Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim*", dated August 6, 2018, prepared by Mr. Eduard Saura and Mr. Nicolas Barsalou; ***(iii)*** Legal Expert Report, dated August 6, 2018, prepared by Mr. David Ramos Muñoz; ***(iv)** "Expert Witness Report on the Nominal Capacity of the Arenales CSP Plant"*, dated July 31, 2018, prepared by Mr. Jesús Casanova Kindelán (submitted in English); and ***(v)*** Expert Report, titled "*Arenales CSP Plant: Useful Life Analysis"*, dated July 28, 2018, prepared by Dr. Jorge Servert and Mr. José Manuel Nieto (submitted in English).

40.

On the same date, the Respondent indicated that it would submit Spanish translations of the documents filed in English with its Rejoinder as soon as possible. The Respondent provided these translations on October 26 and November 19, 2018.

41.

On August 9, 2018, the Respondent submitted a "*Request for Disqualification of the Presiding Arbitrator, Mr. Eduardo Zuleta Jaramillo*" (the "**Request for Disqualification**"), accompanied by Exhibits 1 to 20. On the same date, the Centre informed the Parties that the proceedings were suspended pursuant to Rule 9(6) of the Arbitration Rules, and that the remaining members of the Tribunal would decide on the proposed disqualification, in accordance with Article 58 of the ICSID Convention and Rule 9(4) of the Arbitration Rules.

42.

On August 10, 2018, the Secretary of the Tribunal informed the Parties of the schedule set by the co-arbitrators regarding the Request for Disqualification. According to this schedule: ***(i)*** On August 16, 2018, the Claimant submitted an "*Opposition to the Disqualification of the President of the Tribunal, Dr. Eduardo Zuleta Jaramillo,*" accompanied by Exhibits CR-001 to CR-016; ***(ii)*** On August 21, 2018, Dr. Zuleta Jaramillo submitted observations on the Request for Disqualification; and ***(iii)*** On August 28, 2018, each Party submitted additional observations on the Request for Disqualification.

43.

On September 11, 2018, the co-arbitrators issued a "*Decision on the Kingdom of Spain's Request for Disqualification of Arbitrator Eduardo Zuleta Jaramillo,*" rejecting the Request for Disqualification. Pursuant to Rule 9(6) of the ICSID Arbitration Rules, the proceedings resumed as of that date.

44.

On September 21, 2018, the European Commission submitted to ICSID a "*Request for Leave to Intervene as a Non-Disputing Party*", submitted in English, based on Rule 37(2) of the Arbitration Rules. On the same date, the Secretary of the Tribunal transmitted the Request to the Tribunal and the Parties, and, in accordance with the Tribunal's instructions, asked the European Commission to submit a Spanish translation of its Request as soon as possible. The Tribunal clarified that it would not issue a decision or invite the Parties to submit comments until it had received the translation.

45.

On October 1, 2018, the Claimant submitted a "*Request concerning New Documents and Arguments Introduced by Spain in the Rejoinder.*" On October 8, 2018, the Respondent submitted an "*Opposition to the Claimant's Request concerning New Documents and Arguments Introduced by Spain in the Rejoinder."* On October 16, 2018, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 5, addressing the Claimant's Request of October 1, 2018.

46.

On October 30, 2018, the Tribunal held a preliminary organizational meeting with the Parties via teleconference to discuss procedural, administrative, and logistical matters related to the hearing on jurisdiction, the merits, and damages (the "**Hearing**"). 47.

On the same date, in accordance with the terms of Procedural Order No. 5, the Claimant submitted an *"Additional Memorial on New Arguments Raised by the Kingdom of Spain in the Rejoinder",* accompanied by Exhibits C-0091 to C-0101 and Legal Authorities CL-0147 to CL-0154 (the "**Additional Memorial**").

48.

On November 1, 2018, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 6 regarding the organization of the Hearing.

49.

On November 14, 2018, the European Commission submitted to ICSID a Spanish translation of its September 21, 2018 request for leave to intervene as a non-disputing party. On the same date, the Tribunal Secretary transmitted the translation to the Tribunal and the Parties and, in accordance with the Tribunal's instructions, invited the Parties to submit observations on the European Commission's request. The Parties submitted their observations on November 19, 2018.

50.

On November 21, 2018, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 7, granting the European Commission leave to file a submission exclusively on the issue of the Tribunal's jurisdiction, subject to the following conditions; the submission had to be filed in Spanish no later than November 28, 2018; The submission could not exceed 15 pages; and The European Commission had to expressly undertake to bear any costs arising from its intervention. Additionally, the Tribunal denied the European Commission's requests for access to the case file and for leave to appear at the Hearing.

51.

On November 28, 2018, the European Commission submitted to ICSID a "*Request for Modification of Procedural Order No. 7, dated November 21, 2018, concerning the European Commission's Request to Intervene as a Non-Disputing Party under ICSID Rule 37(2).*" In this document, the European Commission requested that the Tribunal eliminate the Commission's cost commitment and that, *"[i]n the event that the Tribunal… decides not to modify Procedural Order No. 7, the Commission suggests that its request to intervene as a non-disputing party be placed on the record of this case."* In accordance with the Tribunal's instructions, ICSID transmitted a copy of this request to the Parties and invited them to submit observations regarding the same.

52.

On the same date, the Tribunal Secretary informed the Tribunal that ICSID had received a document titled "*Amicus Curiae* Submission" and twelve Exhibits from the European Commission. This documentation was sent exclusively to the ICSID Secretariat without copies to the Members of the Tribunal. In accordance with the Tribunal's instructions, none of these documents were transmitted to the Members of the Tribunal or to the Parties and were retained by the ICSID Secretariat pending further instructions from the Tribunal upon receipt of the Parties' comments.

53.

On November 30, 2018, the Parties submitted their observations on the European Commission's request for modification.

54.

By letter dated December 3, 2018, the Tribunal noted that, according to the information provided by the ICSID Secretariat, the *Amicus Curiae* Submission and its Exhibits totaled more than 800 pages. The Tribunal invited the European Commission to limit its submission to 15 pages, excluding the twelve Exhibits, and indicated that, if this condition was met, the Tribunal would reconsider its decision in Procedural Order No. 7 concerning the Commission's cost commitment, based on the following considerations:

"The Tribunal considers that it is unreasonable to expect the Parties to study and respond to the *Amicus Curiae* Submission and its more than 800 pages of Exhibits in the single week remaining before the hearing. This would place an undue burden on the Parties and unfairly prejudice at least one of them — the Claimant, which opposed the late intervention — if not both. Moreover, the intervention would seriously disrupt the proceedings, as even assuming that the Parties could study and comment on the European Commission's *Amicus Curiae* Submission in just one week, it would still require substantial modifications to the hearing structure to allow the Parties sufficient opportunity to debate the submission."2

Letter to the European Commission dated December 3, 2018, p. 2.

55.

On December 4, 2018, the European Commission submitted to ICSID a new 15-page version of its Amicus Curiae Submission, excluding the Exhibits, and requested that the Tribunal reconsider its cost decision in Procedural Order No. 7. On the same date, ICSID transmitted a copy of the Commission's communication to the Tribunal, without attaching the *Amicus Curiae* Submission, pending further instructions.

56.

By letter dated December 5, 2018, the Tribunal informed the European Commission as follows:

"Given that the European Commission has limited its submission and removed the Exhibits, thereby substantially reducing the risk of disrupting the proceedings and unduly burdening the Parties, the Tribunal will allow the European Commission's intervention, limited to the 15-page submission mentioned above, and will not require the cost condition set forth in Procedural Order No. 7 for this submission, given its limited scope."

57.

On the same date, in accordance with the Tribunal's instructions, ICSID transmitted the European Commission's communication and *Amicus Curiae* Submission to the Parties and informed them that they could refer to the *Amicus Curiae* submission during the Hearing and that, in any event, the Tribunal would provide the Parties with an opportunity to comment in writing on the European Commission's position after the Hearing.

58.

On December 5, 2018, the Respondent requested the Tribunal's authorization to submit into the record the "*Decision on Liability and on Principles for Quantum Assessment*" dated November 30, 2018, issued in the arbitration *RREEF Infrastructure (G.P.) Limited and RREEF Pan-European Infrastructure Two Lux S.à r.l. v. Kingdom of Spain, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/30* (the "**RREEF Decision**" and the "**RREEF**" case). On the same date, the Claimant informed the Tribunal and the opposing Party that one of its experts, Dr. Jürgen Wortmann, would not attend the Hearing.

59.

On that same date, the President of the Tribunal invited the Claimant to comment on the Respondent's request to introduce the RREEF Decision into the record and invited the Respondent to comment on the Claimant's communication regarding the absence of its expert at the Hearing. The Respondent submitted its observations on December 5, 2018, and the Claimant submitted its observations on December 6, 2018.

60.

On December 7, 2018, in accordance with the Tribunal's instructions dated December 6, 2018, the Respondent provided its position regarding whether any confidentiality restrictions applied to the RREEF Decision and whether the Claimant in that arbitration needed to consent before the decision could be provided to this Tribunal.

61.

On December 8, 2018, the Respondent informed the Tribunal and the opposing Party that Dr. José Manuel Nieto would not attend the Hearing in person and proposed that he participate via videoconference.

62.

In accordance with the schedule set out in Exhibit A of Procedural Order No. 1, as updated by letter dated October 10, 2018, the Tribunal and the Parties held the Hearing from December 10 to 15, 2018, in Washington, D.C.

65.

On January 15, 2019, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 8, in which it rejected the Respondent's request to introduce the RREEF Decision into the record and ruled on other pending procedural matters, inter alia, regarding the Hearing transcripts and the Post-Hearing Briefs.

66.

On January 18, 2019, the Respondent requested that the Tribunal reconsider its decision on the submission of the RREEF Decision.

67.

On January 29, 2019, after receiving the Claimant's observations on the Respondent's request for reconsideration, the Tribunal issued Procedural Order No. 9. In this Order, the Tribunal rejected the Respondent's request to submit the RREEF Decision, considering that it was protected by a confidentiality order in force. However, the Tribunal indicated that it could, at its discretion, reconsider this decision should it determine that the RREEF Decision was no longer protected by confidentiality.

68.

On January 31, 2019, the Parties submitted to the Tribunal the agreed corrections to the Hearing transcripts, as well as their points of disagreement.

69.

105.

The Tribunal presents below a summary of the most relevant facts of the dispute, whether agreed upon, undisputed, or determined by the Tribunal.

106.

This dispute concerns certain measures adopted by the Respondent in the renewable energy sector ("**RE Sector**") and the alleged breaches of its obligations under the ECT regarding the Claimant's investments.3

Memorial of Claim, ¶¶ 91 and 100.

107.

Concentrated Solar Power ("**CSP**") technology is a form of solar thermal technology where solar energy is captured in a liquid carrier fluid, which is used to heat thermal oil as a heat transfer fluid ("**HTF**") inside absorption tubes. The HTF converts water into steam using a steam generator, or alternatively, the heat is transferred to a thermal storage system for later use. The generated steam then drives a turbine, which is in turn connected to a generator that produces electricity. The Arenales Plant uses a parabolic trough design, where solar radiation is concentrated on receivers through mirrors or parabolic-trough collectors.4

Estudio Cuatrecasas, Gonçalves Pereira. Legal Audit Report: Proyecto Termosolar Arenales Solar PS, S.L., Cuatrecasas, Gonçalves Pereira S.L.P., July 26, 2011 [**C-0017**].

108.

By using natural gas, CSP plants increase their conversion efficiency from solar energy to electricity and enhance the reliability of their production.

109.

Since the Spanish Constitution of 1978, the Kingdom of Spain has adopted a set of laws governing the Spanish Electricity System ("**SEE**"). The SEE consists of electricity generation, transmission, distribution, and supply, along with electricity consumers and various State regulatory authorities.5

Renewable Energy Plan in Spain 2005-2010, Council of Ministers, August 2005 (**"Plan 2005-2010"**) [**CL-0016; R-0101**].

110.

On November 27, 1997, Spain enacted Law 54/1997,6 which partially opened the electricity sector to competition (with both regulated and liberalized activities) and ended the traditional State-owned public service model. This law established the general legal framework for the electricity sector in Spain, including its guiding principles.

Law 54/1997, dated November 27, 1997, on the Electricity Sector (**"Law 54/1997"** or **"1997 LSE") [CL-0008; R-0003**].

111.

Law 54/1997 distinguished between an "*Ordinary Regime*", applicable to conventional energy production sources (such as coal-fired power plants), and a "*Special Regime*", designed to promote electricity generation from renewable energy sources through various means. The Special Regime applied to electricity production facilities under 50MW that generated electricity from non-consumable renewable energy sources.7

Article 27(1) of Law 54/1997 [**CL-0008; R-0003**].

112.

The law specified that electricity production, except for production under the Special Regime, was considered a liberalized activity.8

Preamble of Law 54/1997 **[CL-0008; R-0003]**.

113.

The Respondent states that this dual regime for electricity generation was intended to promote energy production from sources whose "*competitive market prices were insufficient to cover their construction and operating costs while ensuring a reasonable return on investment. For this reason, such projects required subsidies to be profitable*."9 The Parties do not dispute that, due to the high investment costs, CSP energy generation projects required economic incentives recognized by the Government to compete on cost terms with conventional energy projects.

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶ 293 (emphasis omitted).

114.

The application of the Special Regime was subject to compliance with a series of requirements set forth in the legal and regulatory provisions applicable to the SEE.

115.

Law 54/1997 also provided for a "*reasonable rate of return*" for energy producers. In this regard, Article 30(4) of Law 54/1997 established the following:

"For the determination of premiums, consideration shall be given to the voltage level of energy delivery to the grid, the effective contribution to environmental improvement, primary energy savings, energy efficiency, and the investment costs incurred, in order to achieve reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of money in the capital market."10

Article 30(4) of Law 54/1997 [**CL-0008; R-0003**].

116.

On December 30, 1997, Spain adopted the 2000-2010 Renewable Energy Promotion Plan.11 This Plan assessed the costs that the SEE would incur due to the deployment of renewable energies, based on the reasonable return expected to be granted, and analyzed whether these costs were sustainable for the SEE under a predictable energy scenario.

Spain's 2000-2010 Renewable Energy Promotion Plan, dated December 19, 1999 [**R-0100**].

As the first regulatory development of Law 54/1997, Spain enacted Royal Decree ("**RD**") 2818/199812 on the production of electricity by facilities powered by renewable energy sources, waste, and cogeneration. RD 2818/1998 aimed to establish *"a system of temporary incentives for those facilities that require them to compete in a free market";* to achieve this objective, it determined *"a premium for facilities larger than 50 MW that use non-consumable and non-hydraulic renewable energy sources, biomass, biofuels, or agricultural, livestock, or service waste, in accordance with the provisions of Article 30.5 of the Electricity Sector Law*."13 The regulation allowed for the periodic review and updating of tariffs and premiums applicable to renewable energy ("**RE**") producers.14 Article 32 of this regulation, under the heading "*modifications of premiums and prices*", provided for premium reviews every four years.

Royal Decree 2818/1998, of December 23, 1998, on the production of electricity by facilities supplied by renewable energy resources or sources, waste, and cogeneration ("**RD 2818/1998") [R-0080**]; Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 306; Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 710-712.

d. Article 22 stated that tariffs and premiums established in RD 661/2007 could be reviewed if Spain reached certain installed RE capacity thresholds, but such a review would not apply to facilities already registered in RAIPRE before that date.

e. Article 36 established fixed tariffs and premiums, which would be applicable throughout the entire operational life of each facility.

f. Article 44(1) provided that tariffs, premiums, and upper and lower limits would be adjusted based on fuel price indices and the Consumer Price Index ("**CPI**").

3. Tribunal's Analysis
----------------------

227.

Having considered all the arguments presented by the Parties regarding the intra-EU jurisdictional objection raised by the Respondent, the Tribunal finds that the discussion has centered around five key issues:

(1) What effect does the CJEU's decision in *Achmea* have on the Tribunal's jurisdiction?

(2) Does the ECT impose obligations concerning intra-EU investors and intra-EU investments?

(3) Should this Tribunal give preference to applying EU law?

(4) What effect do European treaties have on obligations under the ECT in light of Articles 30 and 59 of the VCLT?

(5) Should the Tribunal decline jurisdiction over the dispute due to the issue of State aid?

3.2. The Applicability of the ECT to Intra-EU Investors and Investments
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

238.

One of the core aspects of Spain's intra-EU jurisdictional objection is that, according to the Respondent, Article 26 of the ECT refers to disputes between "*a Contracting Party*" and "*an investor of another Contracting Party*," which, in its view, excludes its application in the context of an intra-EU dispute.360 The Respondent cites several provisions of the ECT.361 The argument focuses on Articles 1(2), 1(3), 1(10), and 36(7) of the ECT, which relate to ORIES,362 as well as Articles 16, 25, and 26 of the ECT.363 In Spain's view, the nature of EU law indicates that, by ratifying the ECT, EU Member States did not undertake obligations towards each other under Part III of the treaty.364

In response, Steag argues that Article 26(1) of the ECT, and the absence of a disconnection clause in the body of the ECT, make it clear that intra-EU disputes are not excluded from the scope of the ECT.365 According to Steag, Article 26(1) only requires that the investor be from a Contracting Party and that the Contracting Party not be the same as the Respondent Contracting Party.366 In the Claimant's view, the definitions in the ECT indicate that both the EU and an EU Member State can violate the ECT and be sued by investors from any other Contracting Party.367

The Tribunal finds that the Claimant is correct. The interpretation of the ECT under the general rule of interpretation in Article 31 of the VCLT leads to this conclusion. A reading of the provisions invoked by Spain (namely, Articles 1, 16, 25, 26, and 36 of the ECT) – considering their context and the ordinary meaning of the terms used in the treaty – supports the conclusion that the ECT applies to intra-EU disputes.

241.

The Tribunal's starting point is Article 26(1) of the ECT, which refers to: "*Disputes between a Contracting Party and an investor of another Contracting Party regarding an alleged breach by the former of an obligation under Part III relating to an investment made by the latter in the territory of the former.*" A reading of this provision reveals the absence of an explicit exclusion of intra-EU disputes.368 The interpretation of Article 26(1) of the ECT in light of the definitions set forth in Article 1 of the Treaty confirms this observation and further indicates that there is no implicit exclusion of intra-EU disputes.

See *Blusun S.A. et al. v. Republic of Italy,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/14/3 (December 27, 2016), ¶ 280 [**RL-0068**] (" *On its face there is nothing in the text of the ECT that carves out or excludes issues arising between EU Member States*").

242.

The ECT defines the term "*Contracting Party*" in Article 1(2):

"[...] 'Contracting Party' means a State or a Regional Economic Integration Organization that has agreed to be bound by this Treaty and for which the Treaty is in force."

243.

In turn, Article 1(3) of the ECT provides a definition of "*Regional Economic Integration Organization":*

"[...] 'Regional Economic Integration Organization' means an organization constituted by States to which they have transferred competence over certain matters, some of which are governed by this Treaty, including the power to make binding decisions on those States with respect to such matters."

244.

The term "*territory*" is also expressly defined in the ECT. Under Article 1(10) of the ECT, this term refers to both the territory of a Contracting State and the territory of an ORIE:

"[...] "Territory", *in relation to a State that is a Contracting Party*, means

a) the territory over which it exercises sovereignty, including land, internal waters, and the territorial sea; and

b) in accordance with international maritime law, the sea, seabed, and subsoil, over which the Contracting Party exercises sovereign rights and jurisdiction.

*With respect to a Regional Economic Integration Organization that is a Contracting Party*, the term "territory" shall encompass the 'territories' of the Member States of such organization, as defined in the agreement establishing that organization." (Emphasis added).

245.

The Tribunal finds that these provisions, invoked by Spain to justify the exclusion of intra-EU disputes from the scope of Article 26 of the ECT,369 actually lead to the opposite conclusion. The text of the ECT indicates that there is a diversity of territories when an EU investor brings a claim against an EU Member State, provided that the latter is different from the investor's home country. As explained by the tribunal in *Isolux v. Spain*:

"[...] Both the territory of the Netherlands and the territory of the Kingdom of Spain are part of the territory of the EU as an ORIE. However, the same Article specifies that, concerning a State that is a Contracting Party, "*territory*" means "*the territory over which it exercises sovereignty*." There is no doubt that the Netherlands and the Kingdom of Spain exercise sovereignty over their respective national territories.

Thus, the fact that the "*territory*" of the EU, according to Article 1(10) of the ECT, encompasses the territories of the Netherlands and the Kingdom of Spain does not prevent each of them from also having a "*territory*" within the meaning of the ECT. Only an interpretation of Article 26(1) of the ECT can determine which "territory" must be considered to assess whether the requirement of territorial diversity is met.

[…]

Article 26(1) refers to disputes between "*a Contracting Party and an investor of another Contracting Party... concerning an investment made by the latter in the territory of the former.*" This clearly implies that the relevant territory is that of the Contracting Party against which the investor is acting. In the present dispute, the alleged investment was made in Spain by an investor claiming to be Dutch and who is acting under the ECT against the Kingdom of Spain, not against the EU."370

3.3. The Relevance of EU Law for Determining the Tribunal's Jurisdiction
------------------------------------------------------------------------

254.

The third issue raised by the Parties concerning the intra-EU objection relates to the relevance of EU law to the Tribunal's jurisdiction. Spain argues that it has not consented to submit to arbitration "*issues […] concerning the autonomy and primacy of the [EU legal] order*.384 The Respondent analyzes Article 26(6) of the ECT and contends that it "*prevents an intra-EU investor from bringing an arbitration claim against an EU Member State for its investment*.*"*385 The Claimant, on the other hand, opposes Spain's arguments in this context. According to Steag, EU law is neither applicable nor relevant to determining the Tribunal's jurisdiction.386

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶ 7 (see also ¶¶ 73, et seq. and 84-205). See also Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶¶ 4, 57 and 84-93.

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶ 84.

Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 72, et seq. and 84, et seq.

255.

The Tribunal observes that the Parties' arguments on this point revolve particularly around the interpretation and effects of Article 26(6) of the ECT. The text of this provision is as follows:

"A tribunal established under paragraph (4) shall decide the issues in dispute in accordance with this Treaty and applicable rules and principles of international law."

256.

The Tribunal finds that this clause does not create an obstacle to the exercise of jurisdiction over the present case. Nor does it consider EU law to be determinative for the jurisdictional decision. Four reasons support this conclusion.

257.

*One*. Article 26(6) of the ECT refers only to the law applicable to the merits of the dispute. The Tribunal cannot ignore or overlook the distinction between the law applicable to the merits and the law applicable to jurisdiction.387 A reading of Article 26(6) of the ECT in its context, in accordance with the general rule of interpretation under Article 31 of the VCLT, indicates that the "*issues in dispute*" are precisely those relating to the substantive obligations set forth in Part III of the ECT.388 It cannot be otherwise, as Article 26(1) limits the Tribunal's jurisdiction to disputes concerning Part III of the ECT, and it is therefore in relation to those disputes that the choice of applicable law expressed in Article 26(6) of the ECT applies.389 In *Stadtwerke München v. Spain*, the tribunal aptly explained:

"The Tribunal notes that contrary to what the Respondent argues, the law applicable to the jurisdiction of this Tribunal is not prescribed by Article 26(6) of the ECT but by Articles 26(1)-(5), which confer jurisdiction upon the Tribunal. Article 26(6) of the ECT does not, therefore, assist the Respondent in demonstrating the superiority of EU law or its protection system over the ECT for the purposes of deciding this jurisdictional objection. Article 26(6) governs the law applicable to the merits of the dispute; this is clear from the wording of this provision: "A tribunal established under paragraph (4) shall decide the issues in dispute in accordance with this Treaty and applicable rules and principles of international law." A "dispute" is defined in Article 26(1) as "an alleged breach by [a Contracting Party] under Part III." Part III of the ECT contains the substantive standards of protections, while the dispute resolution provision can be found in Part V of the ECT ("Dispute Resolution"). EU law, and in particular Articles 267 and 344 of the TFEU, as interpreted in *Achmea*, does not, therefore, govern this Tribunal's jurisdiction by virtue of Article 26(6) of the ECT."390

If the drafters of the ECT had intended the scope of Article 26(6) to extend beyond Part III of the ECT, such that it governed the law to be applied by Tribunal to decide whether it had jurisdiction over a dispute, they could have so indicated. 259.

The Tribunal further observes that Article 26(6) of the ECT expresses an agreement between the parties regarding the applicable law for the purposes of Article 42(1) of the ICSID Convention, under which *"[t]he Tribunal shall decide the dispute in accordance with such rules of law as may be agreed by the parties."* The reference in Article 42(1) to "*the dispute*" indicates that the provision concerns exclusively the law applicable to the merits, and not to jurisdiction.392 This is entirely consistent with the interpretation of Article 26(6) of the ECT as a rule concerning the law applicable to the substance of the dispute. In this context, it is useful to refer to the analysis of the tribunal in the case of *Vattenfall v. Germany*:

"Under the ICSID Convention, a jurisdictional objection is clearly demarcated from the merits of the dispute. When Article 42(1) refers to the applicable law when the Tribunal "decides a dispute", it therefore does not include a decision on any jurisdictional objection […] Since the Parties have made an agreement in Article 26(6) of the ECT regarding the applicable law, the default rule in the second sentence of Article 42(1) ICSID Convention does not come into operation. […] In conclusion, Article 26(6) ECT, either viewed through Article 42(1) ICSID Convention or interpreted independently of the ICSID Convention, applies only to the merits of a dispute between the Parties. It does not apply to issues or questions relating to the Tribunal's jurisdiction. For this reason, Respondent's argument that Article 26(6) brings EU law and the ECJ Judgment into application in the context of the Tribunal's jurisdiction must fail."393

262.

*Second.* The Respondent's argument is based on the premise that there is an irreconcilable conflict between EU law and the protection of intra-EU investments and investors under the ECT.400 The Claimant, on the other hand, has emphasized that EU law is compatible with the ECT.401 This Tribunal does not find that the Respondent has demonstrated the existence of a specific incompatibility between a provision of the ECT and EU law. The Respondent asserts but does not explain or prove that the dispute affects EU freedoms. Nor does it substantiate how this proceeding affects the CJEU's competence in applying EU law, thereby endangering the autonomy of EU law.

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶ 63; Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶ 75.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 83 et seq.

263.

The ECT and EU treaties establish fully coherent regimes.402 While the ECT specifically aims to establish "*a legal framework to promote long-term cooperation in the energy sector, based on achieving complementarities and mutual benefits, in accordance with the objectives and principles expressed in the Charter*" (Art. 2 of the ECT), the Preamble and Article 3 of the TEU, as well as the Preamble of the TFEU, indicate that the EU legal system pursues much broader objectives. However, the European integration process does not exclude the existence of a parallel regime in the energy sector, particularly when it has a different scope and involves third States.

See *Blusun S.A. et al. v. Republic of Italy,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/14/3 (December 27, 2016), ¶¶ 292-303 [**RL-0068**].

264.

Specifically regarding Article 26 of the ECT, this Tribunal does not find that there is a conflict between Article 26 of the ECT and Article 344 of the TFEU. Article 26 of the ECT deals with "*disputes between a Contracting Party and an investor of another Contracting Party*," whereas Article 344 of the TFEU regulates the prohibition on Member States from bringing "*disputes concerning the interpretation or application of the Treaties*" of the EU before other tribunals. These are independent provisions, addressing different matters, and, as the Tribunal in *Vattenfall v. Germany* correctly stated, they can coexist and be applied simultaneously.403 The CJEU's decision in *Achmea*, which referred specifically to arbitration under a bilateral treaty between two EU Member States with a seat in the territory of an EU State, as explained in Section 3.1 above, does not affect this conclusion.

*Vattenfall AB et al. v. Federal Republic of Germany*, Decision on the *Achmea* Issue, ICSID Case No. ARB/12/12 (August 31, 2018), ¶ 125 [**CL-0131**]. See also *Stadtwerke München GmbH et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/15/1 (December 2, 2019), ¶¶ 138, et seq. [**RL-0146**].

265.

The Respondent also argues that "*from the moment a dispute affects the fundamental freedoms of the EU and the pillar of State aid, the CJEU is prevented from ensuring the full application of EU law*."404 However, Spain fails to explain why resolving this dispute requires the Tribunal to rule on EU law. As will be explained in Section 3.5 below, the Respondent also fails to demonstrate that resolving the dispute requires determining, in particular, whether the RRO constitutes State aid under EU law.

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 185.

266.

The Tribunal emphasizes that this dispute specifically concerns Spain's obligations under Articles 10(1) and 13 of the ECT. To determine whether the Respondent has breached these obligations, it is not necessary to assess the validity of any EU act.405 Nor is it necessary to determine whether Spain's measures comply with EU law. This Tribunal will assess those measures solely under the ECT and not under EU law. For this reason, the exercise of jurisdiction in this case does not conflict with the competences of the CJEU or other European bodies. Declaring that the measures comply with the ECT or violate it does not imply any determination regarding their compliance with EU law, nor does it preclude competent bodies from making a decision on the matter in the future.

*Third.* The Respondent has focused part of its argument on characterizing EU law as "*applicable international law*" under Article 26(6) of the ECT,406 arguing that EU law has primacy and that this primacy is also recognized in Article 25 of the ECT.407 The Claimant, in turn, analyzes the dualist and monist approaches and argues that, while EU law could be classified as public international law in its origins, today it constitutes a "*distinct and autonomous legal order*."408 According to the Claimant, EU law is not applicable in this context and, in any case, does not prevail over the ECT.409

The Tribunal has already ruled on the scope of Article 26(6) of the ECT, which refers solely to the law applicable to the merits of the dispute and has no effect on the Tribunal's jurisdiction. It has also concluded that EU law is not relevant for determining the Tribunal's jurisdiction. Additionally, in the absence of a collision or inconsistency between the ECT and EU law, the debate over the hierarchy of one over the other loses any practical relevance for the present case.410

For this Tribunal, it cannot be asserted that EU law has primacy over other sources of international law *beyond the scope of the EU legal order*. In *Cube Infrastructure v. Spain*, the tribunal analyzed an argument very similar to the one presented by Spain in this arbitration and concluded:

"To say that EU law is a part of international law and yet has supremacy over other, non-EU components of international law is, in the view of the Tribunal, to mischaracterize EU law and confuse questions belonging to two different legal orders. The EU treaties are, certainly, international agreements of a kind familiar in international law, binding as between the States Parties; but they also function as the constitution of an autonomous community. The rules established by EU secondary legislation are essentially supra-national regulations rather than part of the corpus of international law as such. Similarly, EU law has supremacy *within the EU legal system* over the national laws of the States that are Members of the EU and accordingly subscribe to the EU legal system. Indeed, it appears that they were not asked to do so."415

274.

*Fourth.* As indicated above, Spain has not demonstrated the existence of a conflict or inconsistency between EU law and the provisions of Parts III and V of the ECT. However, even if one were to accept the hypothesis that a conflict exists between the ECT and EU law (*quod non*), this Tribunal must apply the conflict rule established within the ECT itself.417 The ECT's Article 16 provides:

"Article 16. Relationship with other agreements.

When two or more Contracting Parties are signatories to an earlier international agreement, or sign a subsequent international agreement, whose terms affect, in either case, the matters governed by Parts III or V of this Treaty,

1) nothing in Parts III or V of this Treaty shall be interpreted in such a way as to derogate from any provision of the other agreement or from the right to seek dispute resolution under that agreement, and

2) nothing in the other agreement shall be interpreted in such a way as to derogate from any provision of Parts III or V of this Treaty or from the right to seek dispute resolution under this Treaty,

to the extent that such provisions are more favorable to investors or investments."418

See *OperaFund Eco-Invest SICAV PLC and Schwab Holding AG v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/15/36 (September 6, 2019), ¶ 329 [**CL-0162**].

ECT, art. 16 [**RL-0006**].

Article 16 is the provision governing the relationship between the ECT and both prior and subsequent agreements entered into by the Parties, including those of the EU, and resolves any conflict in favor of the provisions that are more favorable to investment or the investor.419 In *BayWa v. Spain*, the tribunal analyzed Article 16 of the ECT and correctly concluded that Article 16 of the ECT requires, as an initial condition, that there be a treaty addressing the same subject matter as Parts III or V of the ECT.420 It is evident that, for the conflict rule to apply, there must first be a conflict.421 That condition, it must be reiterated, is not met in the present case.

*Vattenfall AB et al. v. Federal Republic of Germany*, Decision on the *Achmea* Issue, ICSID Case No. ARB/12/12 (August 31, 2018), ¶¶ 193 [**CL-0131**].

3.4. The Effects of EU Treaties on Obligations under the ECT in Light of Articles 30 and 59 of the VCLT
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

278.

The Respondent argues that there is a conflict between the ECT and EU treaties that should be resolved in accordance with Articles 30 and 59 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties ("**VCLT**"), rather than under Article 16 of the ECT.426 The Claimant acknowledges that EU law could be classified as public international law in its origins, but considers that it has now become an autonomous legal order427 and that if a conflict existed between EU law and the ECT, the ECT would prevail.428

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 186, 194.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 74, 75. See also Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 76, 89. See also Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 11-13, 16 and 31.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 102 et seq.

279.

In Section 3.3 above, the Tribunal ruled on the relationship between EU law and applicable international law. It also found that there is no conflict between EU law and the ECT and that, if a conflict did exist, it would be resolved in favor of the ECT, pursuant to Article 16 of the ECT. In light of the foregoing, the Tribunal need only rule on the Parties' arguments regarding the effects of Articles 30 and 59 of the VCLT on the relationship between the ECT and EU law.

280.

Article 30 of the VCLT establishes the rules that must be considered in determining which treaty applies in the event of incompatibility between the "*rights and obligations*" of the parties in successive treaties on the same subject matter.429

"Article 30. Application of successive treaties relating to the same subject matter.  
1. Without prejudice to the provisions of Article 103 of the Charter of the United Nations, the rights and obligations of States parties to successive treaties concerning the same subject matter shall be determined in accordance with the following paragraphs.  
2. When a treaty specifies that it is subordinate to a prior or subsequent treaty or that it should not be considered incompatible with that other treaty, the provisions of the latter shall prevail.  
3. When all parties to the prior treaty are also parties to the subsequent treaty, but the prior treaty is neither terminated nor its application suspended pursuant to Article 59, the prior treaty shall apply only to the extent that its provisions are compatible with those of the subsequent treaty.  
4. When the parties to the prior treaty are not all parties to the subsequent treaty:  
a) In relations between States that are parties to both treaties, the rule set out in paragraph 3 shall apply.  
b) In relations between a State that is a party to both treaties and a State that is a party to only one of them, their mutual rights and obligations shall be governed by the treaty to which both States are parties.  
5. Paragraph 4 shall apply without prejudice to the provisions of Article 41 and shall not prejudge any issue of termination or suspension of the application of a treaty under Article 60, nor any question of liability that a State may incur for concluding or applying a treaty whose provisions are incompatible with obligations undertaken toward another State under a different treaty."

281.

Article 59 of the VCLT governs the compatibility between a prior and a subsequent treaty in time:430

"Article 59. Termination of a treaty or suspension of its application implied by the conclusion of a subsequent treaty.  
1. A treaty shall be considered terminated if all its parties subsequently conclude another treaty on the same subject matter and:  
a) It is apparent from the subsequent treaty or otherwise evident that the parties intended for the subject matter to be governed by that treaty; or  
b) The provisions of the subsequent treaty are so incompatible with those of the prior treaty that both treaties cannot be applied simultaneously.  
A treaty shall be considered suspended in its application only if it is apparent from the subsequent treaty or otherwise evident that this was the intention of the parties.

282.

The difference between Articles 30 and 59 of the VCLT lies in the fact that while Article 59 refers to the termination of a treaty, Article 30 concerns situations where there are specific inconsistencies between prior and subsequent treaties.431 Article 59 of the VCLT presupposes not only that the two treaties address the same subject matter, but also that it is clear that the parties intended to terminate the earlier treaty, as per Article 59(1)(a), or that there is such an incompatibility that it is impossible to apply both treaties simultaneously, as per Article 59(1)(b).

*Mr. Jürgen Wirtgen et al. v. Czech Republic,* Final Award, PCA Case No. 2014-13 (October 11, 2017). ¶ 260 [**RL-0100**].

283.

The Respondent has not demonstrated compliance with either of these requirements. First, it has not shown that the ECT and EU law address the same subject matter. Nor has it demonstrated that the parties intended to terminate the ECT, in accordance with Article 59(1)(a). As for Article 59(1)(b), the Tribunal reiterates that it has found no incompatibility between the ECT and EU law, which means that there is no impediment to the simultaneous application of both treaties. There is complementarity, not incompatibility — whether substantive or procedural — between the ECT and EU law.

284.

The Parties' arguments regarding Article 30 of the VCLT have focused on Articles 30(3) and 30(4) of the VCLT. This Tribunal begins by noting that these provisions apply when the treaties between which the alleged inconsistency arises do not contain a conflict rule. If a special conflict rule has been agreed upon, it prevails over the provisions of the VCLT (*lex specialis*). The Tribunal notes that in this case, there is an express conflict rule, which is found in Article 16 of the ECT. For the reasons presented in Section 3.3 above, this Tribunal concludes that said rule favors the application of the ECT in the present case. Article 30(3) of the VCLT only applies when "*all the parties to the earlier treaty are also parties to the later treaty*." This requirement is not met between the ECT on one hand and the TEU and TFEU on the other. The Contracting Parties to the ECT include, in addition to EU Member States, the EU itself and third States.

285.

Finally, the Tribunal's conclusion regarding the absence of a conflict between the obligations established in the ECT and those arising from the TEU and TFEU is also relevant for analyzing Articles 30(3) and 30(4) of the VCLT. Indeed, if there are no inconsistencies, Article 30 of the VCLT is inapplicable.

The issue is not whether Spain complied with its obligations under EU law, but rather to determine, as a matter of fact, whether the risk of non-compliance should have been taken into account by the investor (and, if so, to what extent) when committing its capital to the Arenales Solar project.

For these reasons, the arguments put forward by Spain do not raise an issue of the Tribunal's jurisdiction, but rather a potential factual element of the discussion surrounding Steag's expectations, an issue that the Tribunal will consider in its decision on the merits, particularly in relation to the fair and equitable treatment standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT.

The Tribunal also takes note of Spain's argument that an award in favor of Steag could be considered unlawful State aid.445 The Tribunal does not find in this allegation a sufficiently substantiated jurisdictional argument. The argument is based on a series of assumptions about potential future decisions of the European Commission and other EU bodies. However, the Respondent has not demonstrated the existence of a real risk that a favorable award for the investor, protected under the ICSID Convention, would be unenforceable for this reason. Nor does Spain's argument consider that, since this Tribunal is not seated in the territory of an EU Member State, the award is not subject to annulment by the courts of any such State. Furthermore, Spain has not explained to what extent the alleged risk of non-compliance with the award could or should affect the jurisdiction of this Tribunal.

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶ 105.

The Tribunal does not rule out, purely as a hypothesis, that the enforcement of a favorable award for Steag in some jurisdictions, particularly within the territory of EU Member States, may face challenges if Spain's argument on State aid were to be accepted. However, the mere fact that the enforcement of an award might hypothetically be difficult does not mean that the award is unenforceable. The Tribunal's jurisdiction derives from the ECT and the ICSID Convention. The national legal frameworks governing the enforcement of awards do not determine the exercise of jurisdiction conferred upon this Tribunal by those instruments.

Finally, the Tribunal notes that the Parties have briefly referred to Articles 10(7) and 10(8) of the ECT. The Tribunal observes that Article 10(8) refers to: *"[t]he conditions of application of paragraph 7 to programs under which a Contracting Party grants subsidies or other types of financial aid or enters into research and development contracts for energy technologies […]."* The provision indicates that those conditions of application "*shall be reserved for the supplementary treaty mentioned in paragraph 4*". This Tribunal agrees with the Claimant446 that both paragraph 7 and paragraph 4 (which, in turn, refers to paragraph 3 of Article 10 of the ECT) specifically concern obligations regarding more favorable treatment for other investors. None of the cited provisions exclude the application of the obligations established in Articles 10(1) and 13 of the ECT, which are precisely the provisions relevant to Steag's claims.

Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶ 117.

298.

For these reasons, the Tribunal finds that it has jurisdiction over the Parties in this case and rejects the intra-EU objection raised by the Respondent.

The Tribunal observes that the burden of proving that the State did not act in good faith when introducing the TVPEE through Law 15/2012 falls on the Claimant. As a general rule, the party making an allegation must prove it. Steag was therefore required to demonstrate that the TVPEE was not designed to serve Spain's general interest but rather had a malicious objective aimed at harming investments in the sector. The standard for rebutting the presumption of good faith is high. As the tribunal stated in Isolux v. Spain, "*[i]t is not easy to rebut the presumption that the taxation measures enacted by a State are bona fide*."559 Likewise, in Antin v. Spain, the tribunal stated:

"It is well established in international law that an abuse of right claim is subjected to a high threshold of proof. The Tribunal must therefore determine if the TVPEE was adopted by Spain with the precise aim of abusing its rights under the ECT, by strategically creating the TVPEE to curtail the investors' alleged rights under the Treaty, in a manner that abusively sought to employ the taxation exclusion."560

Having reviewed and assessed the evidence presented by the Claimant, the Tribunal finds no proof that the Kingdom of Spain acted in bad faith when enacting Law 15/2012. Steag failed to demonstrate that Spain's intent in introducing the TVPEE was different from what is stated in the preamble of the Law, as cited above. In this regard, the Tribunal agrees with the analysis of the arbitrators in *Isolux v. Spain*:

"[…] The economic repercussions or effects of the TVPEE may be unclear and debatable, but that does not constitute sufficient grounds to conclude that the TVPEE is a tax measure enacted in bad faith.

It is possible that this tax measure does not have the intended environmental impact and that its enactment served no purpose other than to reduce the tariff deficit, as claimed by the Claimant. However, the Arbitral Tribunal does not need to rule on this issue because, if the real purpose of the measure was merely to raise revenue — as the Claimant argues — this would align with the legitimate purpose of any tax, without allowing it to be characterized as a bad faith taxation measure. If it were true that the State presented a purely revenue-generating measure as an environmentally friendly measure, the conclusion would remain the same. It is the actual purpose of the measure that must be assessed by the Tribunal, not its cosmetic presentation, which may be explained by political motives that fall outside the scope of the Arbitral Tribunal's analysis."561

*Isolux Infrastructure Netherlands BV v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, SCC Case No. V 2013/153 (July 12, 2016), ¶¶ 739, 740 [**RL-0003**].

3.1. The tribunal's *ratione temporis* jurisdiction
---------------------------------------------------

368.

With regard to the *ratione temporis* objection, the Parties' arguments have focused on determining the date of the investment and the date on which the dispute arose.673 It is undisputed that the investment was not made before June 8, 2012.674 The issues in dispute are whether a controversy already existed at that time and whether, as the Respondent has suggested, the capital injections made between 2012 and 2014 qualify as "*successive investments*" that must be analyzed separately.675

The Tribunal begins by noting that *ratione temporis* jurisdiction is intrinsically linked to the principle of non-retroactivity in the application of international treaties.676 The treaty — in this case, the ECT — must be applicable to the factual situation to which the arbitration relates, at the time that situation took place.677 It follows that the Tribunal does not have jurisdiction over events that occurred before the treaty's ratification or over events that took place when there was no protected investment.678

*Pac Rim Cayman LLC v. Republic of El Salvador*, Decision on Objections to Jurisdiction, ICSID Case No. ARB/09/12 (June 1, 2012), ¶ 2.101 [**RL-0084**]; *Renée Rose Levy and Gremcitel S.A. v. Republic of Peru*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/11/17 (January 9, 2015), ¶ 147 [**CL-0096**].

*ST-AD GmbH v. Bulgaria*, Award on Jurisdiction, PCA Case No. 2011-06 (ST-BG) (July 18, 2013). ¶ 300 [**RL-0044**].

*Renée Rose Levy and Gremcitel S.A. v. Republic of Peru*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/11/17 (January 9, 2015), ¶ 146 [**CL-0096**].

Based on the above, the central question before the Tribunal for the purposes of the *ratione temporis* jurisdictional objection is the following: Did a protected investment exist when the dispute concerning the investment arose?

371.

The first step in answering this question is determining the date on which the investment was made. The Tribunal finds that the investment was made on June 8, 2012. The Respondent characterizes the capital injections made by Steag after that date as additional "*investments*."679 However, the project structure, based on the evidence presented, does not support Spain's argument.

However, the obligations assumed by the shareholders (sponsors) required them to make additional capital contributions with each disbursement of the approved credit.681 If the cash flows of the special purpose vehicle were insufficient to service the debt, the shareholders (sponsors) would be required to provide additional funds in accordance with the terms and conditions stipulated in the contracts forming part of the project finance structure.
