373.

The Tribunal considers that the fact that the shareholders (sponsors) and lenders agreed to a scheme requiring additional capital injections does not mean that each capital injection constitutes a new investment. The investment is a single one — the acquisition of SMAG's shares in Arenales Solar on June 8, 2012. The additional capital injections correspond to the fulfillment of contractual obligations within the same project, which were undertaken before the NRR was introduced. They are therefore not new "*investments*". All contributions fall within a single transaction.

374.

The economic structure of an operation may result in different capital injections over an extended period, without necessarily implying the existence of multiple independent investments. In this case, Steag made multiple capital injections as part of a single project, beginning on June 8, 2012.682 That is the date of the investment. Furthermore, regardless of the classification of later capital injections as "*investments*," the parties do not dispute that Steag made an investment on June 8, 2012.

See Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 195, et seq.

375.

A separate matter is the relevance of the commitments that Steag undertook after June 8, 2012, for the purpose of determining the Claimant's legitimate expectations and any damages suffered as a result of the alleged ECT violation. However, this is a merits issue rather than a jurisdictional one and will be addressed when discussing the merits of the case.

376.

The second step, taking June 8, 2012, as the date of the investment, is to determine whether a dispute concerning the investment had already arisen by that time.

377.

The relevant portion of Article 26 of the Treaty, regarding disputes that may be submitted to arbitration, states that they are those disputes between a Contracting Party and an Investor of another Contracting Party relating to an Investment of the latter in the Area of the former, which concern an alleged breach of an obligation of the former under Part III ("*Disputes between a Contracting Party and an Investor of another Contracting Party relating to an Investment of the latter in the Area of the former, which concern an alleged breach of an obligation of the former under Part III*").683

ECT, art. 26 [**RL-0006**].

378.

The Treaty does not define what constitutes a "*dispute*." However, in its natural sense, the word "*dispute*" implies a disagreement or conflicting opinions between two or more parties. As the PCIJ stated in the *Mavrommatis* case, a dispute is "*a disagreement on a point of law or fact, a conflict of legal views or interests between two persons*."684 In general terms, a dispute cannot exist if one party has made a statement, declaration, or taken a position on facts or law, and the other party has not expressed any opposition or disagreement.

The Mavrommatis Palestine Concessions, *Greece v. United Kingdom*, CPJI/PCIJ, Ser. A. No 2, (1924) p. 11 [**RL-0024**] [Tribunal's Translation].

379.

The disputes that may be submitted to arbitration under Article 26 of the Treaty are disputes between a Contracting Party and an investor of the other Contracting Party "*relating to Investments*" of the latter and concerning the "*alleged breach*" of obligations under Part III of the ECT. It follows that not every dispute, nor every "*disagreement on a point of law or fact*" between the parties, can be submitted to arbitration under the Treaty. To qualify as a "*dispute*" within the meaning of Article 26 of the ECT, the disagreement must arise in connection with the Claimant's investments in the Respondent's territory and must relate to alleged violations of obligations under Part III of the Treaty.

380.

Based on the above, and in accordance with Article 26 of the Treaty, the Tribunal has jurisdiction to rule on the dispute between the Parties only if the dispute arises from a claim of Treaty violation related to the Claimant's investment in Spain. Any dispute arising from alleged breaches of the Treaty concerning Steag's investment, but which arose before the Claimant acquired Arenales Solar, would not fall within the Tribunal's *ratione temporis* jurisdiction.

381.

Spain has sought to demonstrate that the dispute arose with the publication of the CNE Report on March 7, 2012.685 According to the Respondent, a series of announcements had been made regarding the measures being prepared, and the controversy "*crystallized*" with the issuance of the aforementioned CNE Report. Even the Claimant acknowledges that the measures it claims were announced in 2011 and early 2012 were not approved until December 2012, with Law 15/2012.686

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶ 875.

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 312.

382.

The Tribunal finds that the Respondent's argument is unpersuasive. The Tribunal reiterates that a dispute is a disagreement on a point of law or fact or a conflict of legal positions or interests between two parties. The Respondent's unilateral statements, which were neither objected to nor discussed by the Claimant, cannot be considered expressions of disagreement on a factual or legal point for these purposes. A dispute between Spain and Steag only arises once Spain adopts a measure. It is the adoption of the measure that affects the rights and interests of the investor, who may then oppose it. Until such a measure is enacted, there is no state act capable of causing harm. An announcement is not a legal act and does not impact in any way the rights or legal positions of the affected parties. Such an effect can only be produced by acts that generate legal consequences under the applicable legal framework, which, in this case, is Spanish law. There is no dispute between Steag and the Respondent prior to the date of the investment. Neither the CNE Report nor the acts that "*announced*" the measures alter this conclusion.

383.

Furthermore, the dispute must arise in connection with the Claimant's investments in the Respondent's territory and must relate to alleged breaches of obligations under Part III of the Treaty. The Claimant has made no allegation that any events prior to June 8, 2012, could potentially constitute a violation of the ECT in relation to the Arenales Solar project.

384.

The Claimant is therefore correct in asserting that, for the purposes of *ratione temporis* jurisdiction, the decisive factor is not the *announcement* of the measures but their *approval.*687 The foreseeability of the measures at the time the investment was made is certainly relevant for assessing the investor's legitimate expectations and may therefore impact the success of its claims on the merits. However, the presence or absence of those expectations does not affect the existence of a protected investment for the purposes of the Tribunal's *ratione temporis* jurisdiction. The mere announcement of a measure does not raise a retroactivity issue in the application of the treaty and, therefore, cannot be equated with the adoption of a measure for jurisdictional purposes. A mere announcement is not a legal act; it does not impact in any way the rights or legal positions of the affected parties. Only legal acts produce such an effect. In *Renée Rose Levy v. Peru*, the tribunal stated:

"The determination of the critical date is therefore essential to establishing the Tribunal's *ratione temporis* jurisdiction. In the Tribunal's view, the critical date is the date on which the State adopts the contested measure, even when that measure represents the culmination of a process or series of events that may have begun years earlier."688

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 145; Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, 175, et seq.; *Vito G. Gallo c. Canadá*, Award, UNCITRAL Case (September 15, 2011), ¶ 328 [**RL-0079**] ("*Investment arbitration tribunals have unanimously found that they do not have jurisdiction unless the claimant can establish that the investment was owned or controlled by the investor at the time when the challenged measure was adopted*". Emphasis added).

*Renée Rose Levy and Gremcitel S.A. v. Republic of Peru*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/11/17 (January 9, 2015), ¶ 149 [**CL-0096**] (footnotes omitted).

385.

The contested measure is neither any of the Respondent's "*announcements*" nor the CNE Report. The measures challenged by the Claimant, and in respect of which the dispute exists, were all enacted after the Claimant's investment.

386.

For the reasons set out above, the Tribunal finds that it has *ratione temporis* jurisdiction over this dispute.

3.2. Allegations of abuse of rights
-----------------------------------

387.

As part of its objection to the Tribunal's *ratione temporis* jurisdiction, the Respondent also suggests that Steag may have engaged in an abuse of rights.689 Emphasizing that the timing of the dispute is "determinative" in establishing such abuse,690 Spain argues that "*Steag's supposed investment took place precisely when the conflict had already arisen*."691 The Claimant, in turn, contends that the Respondent has failed to specify in what way Steag allegedly abused its rights.692 In this regard, the Claimant is correct.

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶¶ 867-871.

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶¶ 867-871.

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶¶ 865, 866.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 141; Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 214, 215.

388.

The objection of lack of *ratione temporis* jurisdiction is conceptually distinct from an abuse of rights objection.693 In the present case, the Respondent has not put forward an abuse of rights objection that is sufficiently distinct from its arguments concerning the lack of *ratione temporis* jurisdiction, nor has it presented facts or evidence to substantiate such an objection. It is merely a suggestion embedded within the claim of lack of *ratione temporis* jurisdiction.

See *Pac Rim Cayman LLC v. Republic of El Salvador*, Decision on Objections to Jurisdiction, ICSID Case No. ARB/09/12 (June 1, 2012), ¶ 2.101 [**RL-0084**].

389.

The burden of proving that Steag committed an abuse of rights and, in doing so, acted in bad faith, rests with the Respondent. As recognized by the tribunal in *Philip Morris v. Australia*, the standard that a State alleging abuse of rights must meet is high.694 The Tribunal finds that Spain has not met this burden.

*Philip Morris Asia Ltd. v. Commonwealth of Australia,* Award on Jurisdiction and Admissibility, PCA Case No. 2012-12 (December 17, 2015), ¶¶ 539, 550 [**RL-0037**].

390.

Abuse of rights is closely linked to the requirement of good faith on the part of the investor.

391.

In the present case, there is no indication that Steag held an "*unprotected*" investment before June 8, 2012, and that it structured its investment solely for the purpose of gaining access to jurisdiction under the ECT without being entitled to it. No aspect of the 2012 transaction suggests that Steag abused its rights. Moreover, as previously stated in relation to *ratione temporis* jurisdiction, before June 8, 2012, no measure had been adopted that affected Steag's interests. There is even less reason to suggest an abuse of rights before that date.

392.

For the reasons outlined above, the Tribunal finds that the Respondent has not proven that the Claimant engaged in an abuse of rights. This does not preclude the possibility that events prior to June 8, 2012, may be relevant in assessing the investor's expectations when analyzing the merits of the dispute, particularly concerning the fair and equitable treatment standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT.

393.

In light of the foregoing, the Tribunal rejects the *ratione temporis* objection and the allegations of abuse of rights raised by the Respondent.

----------------------

401.

The Respondent requests that the Tribunal declare the claim regarding the alleged expropriatory effect of the TVPEE inadmissible, arguing that the Claimant failed to fulfill its obligation to submit the matter to the "*competent tax authority*," as required by Article 21(5) of the ECT.722 According to Spain, the "*competent tax authority*" never received such a request from the Claimant.723 Steag contends that it did fulfill its obligation to submit the issue of the alleged expropriatory effect of the TVPEE to the "*competent tax authority*" of the Kingdom of Spain.724 The Claimant asserts that it sent the relevant letter to the President of the Government, who is the hierarchical superior725 of the Minister of Economy and Competitiveness.726 Steag further argues that the Respondent's allegations regarding non-compliance with procedural requirements "*are mere formalism*" and constitute a clear "*distraction to obscure reality*" before the Tribunal.727

402.

Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT provides:

"Where a dispute arises as to whether a tax constitutes an expropriation under Article 13, or as to whether a tax alleged to constitute an expropriation is discriminatory, the following provisions shall apply:

i) The Investor of the Contracting Party alleging such expropriation shall submit the issue of whether the tax is an expropriation or whether it is discriminatory to the competent tax authorities. If neither the Investor nor the Contracting Party submits the issue, the bodies to which disputes are referred under Article 26(2)(c) or Article 27(2) shall submit the issue to the competent tax authority."

403.

There is no dispute between the parties regarding the requirement under Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT to submit matters concerning the alleged expropriatory or discriminatory nature of a tax to the "*competent tax authorities*." Nor is it contested that the TVPEE is a tax. Therefore, the Tribunal must resolve two issues: First, whether the letter effectively "*submitted the issue*" of the alleged expropriatory nature of the tax to the authority. Second, whether the letter was indeed sent to the "*competent tax authority*" designated to address the request.

404.

Regarding the first issue, the Tribunal finds that the letter of May 12, 2014, does not meet the requirement set forth in Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT. The provision clearly states that issues concerning the expropriatory nature of a tax must be "*submitted*" to the competent tax authority. The letter, however, begins by stating that its purpose is "*to notify the existence of a breach by the Kingdom of Spain of [its] obligations toward Steag under Part III of the ECT*."728 It then proceeds to explain the "*origins*" of the alleged breach, attributing it to regulatory changes in Spain's tax framework that directly affected Steag's investments in the renewable energy sector:

"The breach originates in the regulatory changes affecting the financial regime applicable to thermosolar power plants, which were introduced through various regulations: Law 15/2012 of December 27 on fiscal measures for energy sustainability ("Law 15/2012"); Royal Decree-Law 2/2013 of February 1 on urgent measures in the electricity system and financial sector ("RDL 2/2013"); Royal Decree-Law 9/2013 of July 12, which adopts urgent measures to ensure the financial stability of the electricity system ("RDL 9/2013"); Law 24/2013 of December 26 on the Electricity Sector ("LSE"), and its subsequent implementing regulations, currently available as a draft (the future Royal Decree regulating the production of electricity from renewable energy sources, cogeneration, and waste; and the future Order of the Ministry of Industry, Energy, and Tourism approving the remuneration parameters for standard facilities applicable to certain electricity production facilities based on renewable energy sources, cogeneration, and waste)."729

Letter for an amicable settlement sent by Steag to the Kingdom of Spain, dated May 12, 2014 [**C-0005**].

Letter for an amicable settlement sent by Steag to the Kingdom of Spain, dated May 12, 2014 [**C-0005**].

405.

Steag concludes by alleging that the regulatory changes violate the standards of treatment and protection offered by the Kingdom of Spain to investors under the ECT. The letter cites Article 26(1) of the ECT as the basis for "*calling upon*" the competent authority of the Spanish Government to seek an amicable resolution to the dispute.

406.

It is evident that the communication makes no reference to Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT. The letter does not contain the word "*expropriation*" anywhere. There is no indication in the text that the senders intended to consider the tax as expropriatory or that they sought to "*submit the issue of whether the tax is an expropriation*" to the authorities.

407.

The general rule of interpretation set out in Article 31 of the VCLT requires that a treaty be interpreted in good faith and in accordance with the "*ordinary meaning*" of its terms. The key term in this case is "*submit*". The Tribunal must determine whether Steag effectively "*submitted*" the issue of the expropriatory nature of the tax to the competent tax authorities of the Kingdom of Spain. This means assessing whether, in its communication, the Claimant requested that those authorities rule on or clarify the alleged expropriatory nature of the TVPEE. The language used in the document does not reflect a formal notification aimed at prompting the recipients to assess whether the proposed tax could be considered expropriatory. The recipient of the letter could not reasonably understand or infer, based on its text, that they were being asked to initiate the process set forth in Article 21(5) of the ECT.

408.

For the Tribunal, the above is already sufficient to conclude that the Claimant did not submit the issue of the expropriatory nature of the TVPEE to the competent tax authority. However, the Tribunal will also address Spain's second argument. On this point, the Tribunal notes that Article 21(7)(c) of the ECT730 states:

"[C]ompetent tax authority" means the competent authority under a double taxation treaty in force between the Contracting Parties or, where no such treaty is in force, the Minister or Ministry responsible for taxation or their authorized representatives."

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 132, referring to Article 3(1)(g) of the Double Taxation treaty between the Federal Republic of Germany and the Kingdom of Spain (February 3, 2011) [**CL-0094**].

409.

From Article 21(7)(c), it follows that, in this case, the "*competent tax authorities*" are those designated under the bilateral double taxation treaties concluded between the Kingdom of Spain and the Federal Republic of Germany.731 The Claimant submitted to the record the "*Convention for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion with Respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital*" (Exhibit **CL-094**), concluded between Spain and Germany. Article 3(1)(g) of the Convention states that the "*competent authority*" in Spain is "*the Minister of Economy and Finance or their authorized representative*."732

Instrument of Ratification of the Treaty between the Kingdom of Spain and the Federal Republic of Germany for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Tax Evasion with respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital, and its Protocol, executed in Madrid on February 3, 2011 [**CL-0094**].

Instrument of Ratification of the Treaty between the Kingdom of Spain and the Federal Republic of Germany for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Tax Evasion with respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital, and its Protocol, executed in Madrid on February 3, 2011 [**CL-0094**].

410.

The Tribunal finds that the requirements of Article 21(5)(b) may be satisfied by a letter, provided that it is properly formulated and addressed to the Respondent's competent tax authority. Thus, it would be sufficient for a Claimant to "*submit*" the issue of the expropriatory nature of the TVPEE to the Minister of Finance of Spain.

411.

In the Reply on the Merits and Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, as well as the Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, the Claimant asserts that it sent a letter to the Spanish Government on May 12, 2014, seeking an amicable resolution to the dispute.733 It reiterates that the letter was sent to the President of the Government, as the hierarchical superior within the Spanish State structure.734 However, nothing indicates that the letter was addressed to the Spanish Minister of Finance

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 128, 129; Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶ 166.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 131; Rejoinder on Jurisdiction, ¶ 169.

412.

The term "*competent tax authority*" is explicitly defined in the ECT, which expressly and unequivocally refers to a "*double taxation treaty in force between the Contracting Parties.*" Since such an agreement exists between Spain and Germany and provides a clear definition of "*competent tax authority*," it is that authority — and no other — to whom the relevant request must be submitted. This Tribunal cannot overlook the plain and unequivocal wording of the ECT. It is not sufficient for Steag to have sent a communication to any official within the Spanish State structure, regardless of their seniority. Moreover, the Claimant has not presented a clear argument that would allow the Tribunal to conclude that any of the officials who received the May 12, 2014 letter qualify as the "*competent tax authority*" under the ECT.

413.

In sum, the Claimant has not demonstrated that its May 12, 2014 letter was sent to a "*competent tax authority*," as defined in the ECT and as designated under the Double Taxation Treaty between Spain and Germany. Furthermore, the content of the letter itself does not indicate that the Claimant was requesting the authority to assess the potential expropriatory effects of a fiscal measure.

414.

Consequently, the Tribunal concludes that the Claimant did not submit the issue of the alleged expropriatory nature of the 7% tax on electricity production, established under Law 15/2012, to the "*competent tax authority.*" As a result, it failed to comply with the procedural requirement set out in Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT. Accordingly, the claim regarding the alleged violation of Article 13 of the ECT through the introduction of the TVPEE is deemed inadmissible.

415.

The Tribunal declines to independently refer the issue of the TVPEE's expropriatory nature to the Spanish authority, as doing so would cause an unnecessary delay in resolving the matters before this Tribunal. The Tribunal notes that the Claimant's arguments under Article 13 of the ECT pertain to the RRO as a whole and do not present a sufficiently differentiated argument regarding the expropriatory nature of the TVPEE specifically. In any event, a determination by the Spanish authority would not alter the Tribunal's conclusions reached in paragraphs 679 and 680 of this decision. The Tribunal emphasizes that, consequently, a decision by the Spanish Minister of Economy and Finance or their authorized representative would not lead to a different outcome in these proceedings.

3. Tribunal's Analysis
----------------------

499.

The Claimant alleges that the Respondent breached its obligation to provide FET protection to its investment under Article 10(1) of the ECT, which states:

"In accordance with the provisions of this Treaty, the Contracting Parties shall encourage and create stable, equitable, favorable, and transparent conditions for investors of other Contracting Parties to make investments in their territories. Such conditions shall include **a commitment to accord at all times to investments of investors of other Contracting Parties fair and equitable treatment.** These investments shall also enjoy full protection and security, and no Contracting Party shall impair them in any way by unreasonable or discriminatory measures affecting their management, maintenance, use, enjoyment, or disposal. In no case shall such investments be accorded treatment less favorable than that required by international law, including treaty obligations [...]."1073

ECT, art. 1 [**RL-0006**] (emphasis added).

500.

The Tribunal begins by noting that, as pointed out by the Respondent, the burden of proving a violation of the FET standard lies with Steag.1074 The Claimant's arguments can be divided into two main points:

(i) The first concerns the alleged violation of the standard due to the frustration of Steag's legitimate expectations.1075 The Claimant contends that RD 661/2007, the 2010 ER Communication, and RD 1614/2010, together with the registration of the Arenales Project in the pre-assignment registry, created an expectation that there would be no unjustified substantial changes to the project's remuneration.1076 The investor could not have foreseen fundamental changes to the system.1077 The Respondent allegedly breached this expectation by adopting the NRR, which led to "*the abolition of guaranteed tariffs for electricity production and their replacement with the New Regulatory Regime, which provides for a 'reasonable return' ratio as Steag's investment remuneration*."1078

(ii) The second argument is that, under the ECT, the FET standard includes a guarantee of stability.1079 In this regard, Steag asserts that: "*Even if it were understood that the fair and equitable treatment standard corresponds to an international minimum that does not include the protection of investors' legitimate expectations, it certainly protects against drastic changes that are unreasonable and inconsistent, for which it will be necessary to take into account precisely the legitimate expectations generated for the investor*."1080

The Tribunal will now analyze each of these arguments separately.

3.1. Steag's Legitimate Expectations
------------------------------------

502.

The Parties do not dispute that the frustration of a protected investor's legitimate expectations may constitute a violation of the FET standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT. The Tribunal agrees with the Parties that this is one of the core functions of the FET standard.1081

*Electrabel S.A. v. Hungary*, Decision on Jurisdiction, Applicable Law, and Liability, ICSID Case No. ARB/07/19 (November 30, 2012), ¶ 7.75 [**RL-0002**].

503.

However, not every expectation of an investor is relevant for establishing a violation of Article 10(1) of the ECT.1082 The concept of "*legitimate expectations*" has been refined in numerous arbitral decisions regarding Article 10(1) of the ECT. In general, these decisions have indicated that expectations must be objectively established, exist at the time of the investment, and be based on the State's positive conduct.1083

*RREEF Infrastructure (G.P.) Ltd. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Decision on Liability and the Principles for Quantum Assessment, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/30 (November 30, 2018), ¶¶ 260, 261 [**RL-0140**].

*Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶ 536 [**CL-0130**]; *Mr. Jürgen Wirtgen et al. v. Czech Republic*, Final Award, PCA Case No. 2014-13 (October 11, 2017), ¶¶ 407, 411 [**RL-0100**].

504.

For the purposes of this case, the first step is to determine which actions of the Respondent were capable of generating a legitimate expectation regarding Steag's investment as of the investment date, i.e., June 8, 2012 **(a)**. It is also necessary to establish to what extent the State's conduct was a decisive factor in Steag's decision to invest in Spain, which requires examining the investor's conduct and the information it knew or should have known at the time of the investment **(b)**. If the Tribunal finds that there is an objective basis for the formation of legitimate expectations and that the acts capable of generating expectations played a role in the decision to invest in Spain, the Tribunal must then determine what Steag's expectations actually were, i.e., their scope **(c)**. Once this analysis is complete, the Tribunal must assess the extent to which the adoption of the NRR frustrated those expectations **(d)**.

*a) Acts of the Respondent Capable of Generating Legitimate Expectations Regarding Steag's Investment*
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

505.

There is a degree of consensus that the creation of legitimate expectations requires acts attributable to the State that are objectively capable of generating those expectations. However, there is debate as to whether those acts must necessarily consist of specific representations to one or more particular investors or under what conditions general measures can give rise to legitimate expectations.1084

*Electrabel S.A. v. Hungary*, Decision on jurisdiction, applicable law, and liability, ICSID Case No. ARB/07/19 (November 30, 2012), ¶ 7.76 [**RL-0002**]; *Parkerings-Compagniet AS v. Republic of Lithuania*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/05/8 (September 11, 2007), ¶ 331 [**CL-0033**].

506.

Some tribunals constituted under the ECT have found that, although the elements of a regulatory regime may be directed at certain specific investors, "*this does not make them commitments specifically addressed to each of them*."1085 It has been argued that *"[c]onverting a regulatory rule, by virtue of the limited number of persons subject to it, into a specific commitment made by the State to each of these subjects, would constitute an excessive limitation on the ability of States to regulate the economy in the public interest*.*"*1086

*Charanne BV et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Final Award, SCC Case No. V 062/2012 (January 21, 2016), ¶ 493 [**RL-0049**].

*Charanne BV et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Final Award, SCC Case No. V 062/2012 (January 21, 2016), ¶ 493 [**RL-0049**].

507.

Other tribunals have found that the regulatory framework in highly regulated industries can give rise to legitimate expectations. In *Cube Infrastructure v. Spain*, the tribunal explained:

"The Tribunal does not find it necessary for a specific commitment to have been made to each individual claimant for a legitimate expectation to arise. At least in the case of a highly regulated industry, and as long as the representations are sufficiently clear and unequivocal, it is sufficient that a regulatory regime is established with the manifest purpose of attracting investments, offering potential investors the prospect that their investments will be subject to a set of regulatory principles that, as a deliberate policy, will remain in force for a finite period of time. Such regimes are clearly designed to create expectations, which investors will rely on; and insofar as those expectations are objectively reasonable, they give rise to legitimate expectations when investments are actually made based on them."1087

Translation of the Tribunal. Original text: *Cube Infrastructure Fund SICAV et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Decision on Jurisdiction, Liability, and Partial Decision on Damages, ICSID Case No. ARB/15/20 (February 19, 2019), ¶ 388 [**CL-0158]**. (" *The Tribunal does not consider it necessary that a specific commitment be made to each individual claimant in order for a legitimate expectation to arise. At least in the case of a highly-regulated industry, and provided that the representations are sufficiently clear and unequivocal, it is enough that a regulatory regime be established with the overt aim of attracting investments by holding out to potential investors the prospect that the investments will be subject to a set of specific regulatory principles that will, as a matter of deliberate policy, be maintained in force for a finite length of time. Such regimes are plainly intended to create expectations upon which investors will rely; and to the extent that those expectations are objectively reasonable, they give rise to legitimate expectations when investments are in fact made in reliance upon them*"). See also *9Ren Holding S.à.r.l. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/15/15 (May 31, 2019), ¶ 295 [**CL-0157**] ("*There is no doubt that an enforceable 'legitimate expectation' requires a clear and specific commitment, but in the view of this Tribunal there is no reason in principle why such a commitment of the requisite clarity and specificity cannot be made in the regulation itself where (as here) such a commitment is made for the purpose of inducing investment, which succeeded in attracting the Claimant's investment and once made resulted in losses to the Claimant*"); *Charanne BV et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Dissenting Opinion of Dr. Guido Santiago Tawil, SCC Case No. V 062/2012 (January 21, 2016), ¶ 12 (*"[…] when an investor meets all the requirements established by the applicable regulations to be entitled to a specific and determined benefit, its subsequent disregard by the host State violates a legitimate expectation"*).

508.

It cannot be established as a general rule that legal norms are always capable of generating legitimate expectations. But neither can it be affirmed, as a general rule, that legal norms cannot generate legitimate expectations or crystallize specific commitments. Everything depends on the specific case. An investor's expectations may arise from administrative acts, legislative provisions, contracts, or other acts attributable to the State, or a combination thereof, depending on the circumstances of the case.1088 When legal norms give substance to particular and specific administrative acts, the commitment may arise from the combination of both. The existence or absence of a specific commitment should not be examined through an abstract discussion on the legislative, administrative, or contractual nature of the relevant acts. What is fundamental is whether, in the particular circumstances of the case, there are acts attributable to the State that, individually or collectively, could generate a specific expectation in the investor.

See 1404 *Frontier Petroleum Services Ltd. v. The Czech Republic*, Award, UNCITRAL Case (November 12, 2010), ¶ 285 [**CL-0111**].

509.

This Tribunal finds that, in the specific case of Steag, as presented before this Tribunal, it is not necessary to address the debate on whether a specific legal or regulatory provision can create a legitimate expectation. There is no dispute that a specific commitment by the State to an investor can create a legitimate expectation, and in the case of Arenales Solar, the Tribunal finds that there were specific acts by the Spanish State relating to the project which, within the context of the relevant legislation, were capable of generating legitimate expectations. Specifically, the Spanish State issued a resolution in favor of Arenales Solar registering it in the pre-assignment register for remuneration, which constitutes a particular and concrete administrative act rather than a general legal or regulatory norm. This administrative act, applicable only to its recipient, explicitly, specifically, and unequivocally stated that the installation would benefit, under the terms and conditions established in the applicable regulatory framework, from the economic regime of RD 661/2007.

510.

The Resolution of Registration of Arenales Solar is, therefore, a specific act that expresses a specific commitment by the Spanish State. Steag is correct in asserting that the register was capable of generating legitimate expectations:1089

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 340.

511.

To begin with, the very title of the resolution indicates that it had effects beyond a mere administrative registration: "*Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines by which the installation ARENALES, whose owner is ARENALES SOLAR PS, S.L., is registered in the Pre-Assignment Register for Remuneration, **granting it the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007, dated May 25***."1090

Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines registering the ARENALES facility, owned by ARENALES SOLAR PS, S.L., in the Pre-Assignment Register, granting it the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007 of May 25, 2007 [**C-0009**]; (emphasis added).

512.

The rationale section of the resolution explicitly states: "*In accordance with the provisions of paragraph 1 of the fifth transitional provision of the aforementioned Royal Decree-Law [RDL 6/2009], **the economic regime of installations registered in the Pre-Assignment Register for Remuneration pursuant to the provisions of the fourth transitional provision of the same, shall be as provided in Royal Decree 661/2007**, dated September 26*."1091

Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines registering the ARENALES facility, owned by ARENALES SOLAR PS, S.L., in the Pre-Assignment Register, granting it the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007 of May 25, 2007 [**C-0009**]; (emphasis added).

513.

The legal effects of a particular and specific administrative act, such as this resolution, depend on the legislation within which the act in question was issued. This is why the significance of this specific representation can only be understood through a comprehensive reading of the legal framework applicable to the pre-assignment remuneration register.

514.

Article 9 of RD 661/2007 requires the registration of special regime production installations in what was called the "*Administrative register of special regime production installations*."1092 Section 4 of RDL 6/2009 establishes the "*Pre-Assignment Register for the Special Regime*."1093 The Tribunal observes that various provisions of RD 1614/2010 express the relevance and effects of registration in the RAIPRE and the pre-assignment register for solar thermal power plants (see Arts. 2.3, 2.4, 4). The Parties dispute the function of this register.

RDL 6/2009, section 4 [**CL-0020**; **R-0072**].

515.

For Spain, the register served a mere administrative function; it was a "*mandatory administrative register*" that had no significance beyond being a "*regulatory requirement for obtaining subsidies*."1094 For Steag, when the Spanish State faced the tariff deficit, the pre-assignment register was used to maintain legal certainty for investors; the register modulated the start of plant operations, taking into account the capacity to absorb installed power.1095 Steag argues that RDL 6/2009 also aimed to protect investments in renewable energy.1096 For the investor, there was an expectation of stability derived from registration in the pre-assignment register.1097

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶ 912.

516.

The Tribunal cannot accept Spain's position that it was merely a "*regulatory requirement for obtaining subsidies.*"

517.

The pre-assignment register cannot be analyzed in isolation but within the legal framework under which it was created and considering the successive regulatory provisions adopted by Spain after its creation.1098

In other ECT cases, it has already been concluded that registration in the RAIPRE was not a mere "*administrative requirement*" but entailed significant legal consequences. *Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 552 [**CL-0130**].

Specifically, Article 2 of RDL 1/2012, dated January 27, 2012, suspended the pre-assignment remuneration processes but explicitly protected installations that had already been registered or were in the process of registration.

"Article 2. Scope of application.

1. This Royal Decree-Law shall apply to the following installations:

[...]

2. This Royal Decree-Law **shall not apply to special regime installations that had submitted an application for registration in the Pre-Assignment Register for Remuneration** when the corresponding resolution deadline, under the provisions of Articles 2 and 3 of Article 42 of Law 30/1992, of November 26, on the Legal Regime of Public Administrations and Common Administrative Procedure, had already expired at the date of its entry into force".1099

RDL 1/2012, Art. 2 [**R-0074**] (emphasis added).

519.

The registration resolution for Arenales Solar, therefore, carries a meaning that goes far beyond the mere certification of compliance with an administrative requirement. Within the regulatory framework of Spanish law, the registration materializes the promise of providing a certain degree of stability in the economic regime applicable to the installation. Spain, through the express terms of the Arenales Solar registration resolution, "*granted the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007*."1100 The rules governing the final registration under RD 661/2007 and the pre-assignment registration under RDL 6/2009, collectively, made it reasonable to infer that this resolution ensured a certain level of protection against future changes. RDL 1/2012 and RD 1614/2010 confirmed this interpretation and, as will be seen later, clarified the scope of this guarantee.

Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines registering the ARENALES facility, owned by ARENALES SOLAR PS, S.L., in the Pre-Assignment Register, granting it the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007 of May 25, 2007 [**C-0009**].

520.

When the State grants an investor a specific status through a particular and concrete administrative act, which domestic law endows with certain legal effects, the combination of the administrative act and the rules that give it substance can generate legitimate expectations. In such cases, the expectation does not arise from general legislation considered in isolation, but rather from a particular act to which legislation attributes specific legal effects. In a situation like the present one, where the administration directly addressed a specific party (Arenales Solar) through a registration resolution, and the legislature itself defined the effects of that administrative declaration, there is a clear and solid basis for the formation of legitimate expectations. Given that these acts generate legal effects under the law of the host State, it could be argued that such a situation creates an even stronger commitment than a mere non-binding statement or communications between an investor's representatives and a State official.

521.

The Tribunal notes that, according to Spain, the pre-assignment register could not generate legitimate expectations because it might be incompatible with the EU State aid regime. The Tribunal finds that such a potential incompatibility does not prevent the Spanish State's positive acts described above from giving rise to a legitimate expectation.

522.

Firstly, there is no decision from an EU body clearly indicating that the RRO violates EU law. Moreover, if there were a contradiction with EU law, it would imply that the Spanish State had failed to comply with its obligations under EU law. Under the principle of good faith in international law, the State cannot be allowed to use its own unlawful conduct as a means to escape liability under the FET standard; *nemo auditur propriam turpitudinem allegans*. Furthermore, Steag is correct in arguing that the duty to conduct due diligence before making an investment does not require anticipating an international violation.1101

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 255.

*b) The relevance of Steag's conduct and due diligence before the investment date in determining the existence and scope of legitimate expectations*
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

523.

For the purposes of the FET standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT, an investor's legitimate expectations must be determined not in abstract terms but in light of the specific circumstances surrounding the investment decision and at the time of the investment itself. In addition to the existence of State acts capable of generating an expectation, it must be demonstrated that these acts actually motivated the investment or, at the very least, were considered in the investment decision.

524.

This analysis involves establishing what information the investor knew or should have known at the time of making the investment. The investor cannot rely on subjective expectations arising from a negligent lack of knowledge of the applicable regulatory framework. In this sense, the investor bears the burden of adequately informing itself about the circumstances of the location where it intends to invest.

525.

In *Parkerings v. Lithuania*, the tribunal explained:

"The investor will have a right of protection of its legitimate expectations provided it exercised due diligence and that its legitimate expectations were reasonable in light of the circumstances. Consequently, an investor must anticipate that the circumstances could change, and thus structure its investment in order to adapt it to the potential changes of legal environment."1102

Translation of the Tribunal. Consequently, an investor must anticipate that the circumstances could change, and thus structure its investment in order to adapt it to the potential changes of legal environment*". *Parkerings-Compagniet AS v. Republic of Lithuania,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/05/8 (September 11, 2007), ¶ 333 [**CL-0033**].

*c) Scope of the expectation*
-----------------------------

533.

The legitimate expectations relevant to determining a violation of the FET standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT are those that existed at the time of investment, which in this case is June 8, 2012. The investment date marks a fundamental difference compared to the factual circumstances analyzed by various tribunals under the ECT. Within the context of the SEE and the measures adopted by Spain after Royal Decree 661/2007, investing in 2009 is not the same as investing in 2012. To determine what expectations Steag could have had in June 2012, it is first necessary to consider the evolution of the applicable regulatory framework up to that point.

534.

The Tribunal has established that obtaining the resolution for registration in the pre-assignment register1118 could generate legitimate expectations. It is also clear that the pre-assignment registration was a circumstance that was specifically considered in the due diligence reports conducted before the investment date. However, the Parties dispute the object of Steag's expectation.

Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines registering the ARENALES facility, owned by ARENALES SOLAR PS, S.L., in the Pre-Assignment Register, granting it the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007 of May 25, 2007 [**C-0009**].

535.

The Claimant explains that within the regulatory framework designed by Spain to attract investments, "*[o]perators assumed that, once registered in the RAIPRE, projects would be promoted in accordance with the regulatory framework of RD 661/2007*."1119 Specifically, Steag argues that "*Spain created in the Claimant the legitimate expectation that the regulation of thermosolar energy for facilities registered in the pre-assignment remuneration register would not undergo drastic changes*."1120 The Claimant asserts that, in its understanding, "***tariffs applicable to thermosolar energy** would only be revised in the future and would not negatively affect existing plants*."1121 Spain, on the other hand, contends that this expectation lacks foundation because Spanish law only guaranteed a reasonable return, not the fossilization of the regulatory regime.1122

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 379.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 349, et seq.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 373 (emphasis added).

Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶¶ 908, 910.

536.

The Tribunal begins by noting that both Parties agree that Spanish law guarantees a reasonable return. By the time of investment, the concept of reasonable return had been a constant feature in the evolution of Spain's legal framework. The principle of reasonable return appears in the Electricity Sector Law (LSE) of 1997,1123 in RD 436/2004,1124 in RDL 7/2006,1125 RD 661/2007,1126 RD 1614/20101127 and RDL 1/2012.1128 In this regard, this Tribunal concurs with the conclusion of the award in *RREEF v. Spain*, where it was held that "*A reasonable return or reasonable profit was undoubtedly part of the guarantees granted to the Claimants — and, more broadly, to all investors in the Spanish RE sector*."1129 The issue in this case is whether Steag had an expectation of additional stability, beyond the general concept of reasonable return referred to in the cited provisions or, in other words, whether Steag had a legitimate expectation that a certain level of profitability, previously established by Spain as reasonable return, would be maintained.

Article 30.4 of the 1997 LSE stipulated for special regime installations that "*For the determination of premiums, consideration shall be given to the voltage level of energy delivery to the grid, the effective contribution to environmental improvement, primary energy savings, energy efficiency, and the investment costs incurred, **in order to achieve reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of money in the capital market***" [**CL-0008**; **R-0003]** (emphasis added).

The First Additional Provision of Royal Decree 436/2004 stated: "*The economic regime of these installations shall particularly consider their effective contribution to environmental improvement, primary energy savings, and energy efficiency. It shall also take into account the investment costs incurred to ensure **reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of money in capital markets.*****" [CL-0015; R-0082**] (emphasis added)

RDL 7/2006, Article 1.13, which amends Article 30 of Law 54/1997, refers to the goal of "*achieving **reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of money in the capital market***" [**R-0071**] (emphasis added).

Article 44(3) of RD 661/2007, which referred to the revision of tariffs, premiums, supplements, and upper and lower limits (discussed in section 1.3.1 above), stated that revisions would be made "***always guaranteeing reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of money in the capital market***" [**CL-0018; R-0084**] (emphasis added).

The Preamble of RD 1614/2010 indicated that "*the support scheme, as formulated, must be adapted — **while safeguarding the legal certainty of investments and the principle of reasonable return** — to the evolving reality of the learning curves of the different technologies and to the technical constraints that emerge with their increased penetration in the generation mix*" [**CL-0022; R-0088**] (emphasis added).

Article 3 of RDL 1/2012 reiterates the guarantee of "*reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of money in the capital market*", even for new installations [**R-0074**].

*RREEF Infrastructure (G.P.) Ltd. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Decision on Liability and on Principles for Quantum Assessment, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/30 (November 30, 2018), ¶ 381 [**RL-0140**].

537.

After analyzing the Parties' arguments and the evidence on record, the Tribunal finds that Steag did have an expectation of stability regarding a specific level of return, which had been defined as reasonable and which went beyond the mere concept of reasonable return. This expectation, as will be further explained below, related exclusively to three elements of the economic regime under RD 661/2007, namely: ***(i)*** Tariffs; ***(ii)*** Premiums; and ***(iii)*** and Lower and upper limits This conclusion is derived not only from an analysis of the laws that, in their entirety and prior to the investment date, embodied the economic promise inherent to Arenales Solar's registration in the pre-assignment register, but also from the Claimant's own arguments and statements.

(i) The significance of Arenales Solar's pre-assignment registration within the regulatory framework in force at the time of the registration resolution's issuance
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

538.

The Tribunal has determined that the Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines, dated December 11, 2009, registers Arenales Solar in the pre-assignment remuneration register and "*grants it the economic regime regulated under Royal Decree 661*."1130 The scope of this resolution can only be understood by analyzing it in conjunction with the other provisions of the regulatory regime that were in force at that time.

Resolution of the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines registering the ARENALES facility, owned by ARENALES SOLAR PS, S.L., in the Pre-Assignment Register, granting it the regulated economic regime under Royal Decree 661/2007 of May 25, 2007 [**C-0009**].

539.

The starting point must be,1131 which introduced a remuneration system for electricity production under the special regime. The system established by this decree provided, *inter alia*:

(i) The option of remuneration through either the fixed tariff option or the regulated tariff option, as set out in Articles 17(c)1132 and 24(1).1133 Article 17(c) clarifies that "*[t]he right to receive the regulated tariff, or, as the case may be, a premium, shall be subject to the definitive registration of the installation in the Special Regime Production Installations Register under the Directorate General for Energy Policy and Mines, prior to the deadline established in Article 22*."1134

(iii) Article 2(1)(b)(1) of RD 661/2007 allowed certain installations to benefit from the special regime, including "*facilities that use as their primary energy source non-consumable renewable energies, biomass, or any type of biofuel, as long as their owner does not engage in production activities under the ordinary regime*." The regulation established specific subcategories of installations. Subgroup b.1.2 covered "*[i]nstallations that use only thermal processes to convert solar energy, as primary energy, into electricity*. *These installations may use equipment that utilizes a fuel to maintain the temperature of the heat transfer fluid to compensate for the lack of solar irradiation that could affect the expected energy output. The electricity generation from such fuel must be less than, on an annual basis, 12% of the total electricity production if the installation sells its energy under option (a) of Article 24.1 of this Royal Decree* [regulated tariff per kilowatt-hour]. *This percentage may reach up to 15% if the installation sells its energy under option (b) of the aforementioned Article 24.1* [market price plus premium]."

(iii) Based on Article 17(b), the right to "*[t]ransfer to the system, through the distribution or transmission company, its net electricity production or sold energy, provided that its absorption by the grid is technically possible."*

(iv) Article 17(e) granted special regime installations the right to "*[p]riority access and connection to the electricity grid under the terms set out in Exhibit XI of this Royal Decree or in the regulations that replace it*."

(v) The decree granted remuneration for the useful life of the plants, in accordance with Article 36, which differentiated between various categories. According to the Fröhlingsdorf Report,1135 Arenales Solar was classified under group b.1.2, entitling it to a regulated tariff of 26.9375 c€/kWh for the first 25 years, with a reference premium of 25.4000. After this 25-year period, the regulated tariff was set at 21.5498 c€/kWh, with a reference premium of 20.3200. For plants in this group, an upper limit of 34.3976 c€/kWh and a lower limit of 25.4038 c€/kWh were established.

(vi) Article 44.1 provided a mechanism for the "*updating and review of tariffs, premiums, and supplements.*" Article 44.3 specifically foresaw "*the review of the tariffs, premiums, supplements, and upper and lower limits defined in this Royal Decree, taking into account the costs associated with each of these technologies, the level of participation of the special regime in meeting demand, and its impact on the technical and economic management of the system, always guaranteeing reasonable rates of return with reference to the cost of capital in financial markets. Every four years thereafter, a new review will be carried out, maintaining the previous criteria."* The second paragraph of this provision stated that *"[t]he reviews referred to in this section of the regulated tariff and of the upper and lower limits **shall not affect installations whose commissioning certificate was issued before January 1 of the second year following the year in which the review was conducted**."*1136

RD 661/2007 [**CL-0018**; **R-0084**].

Thus, Article 17(c) of RD 661/2007 provides that producers under the special regime have the right to: "*c) Receive payment for the sale, in whole or in part, of their net generated electricity in any of the options set out in Article 24.1, as stipulated in the economic regime of this royal decree […]*" [**CL-0018**; **R-0084**].

Article 24.1 of RD 661/2007 states that: *"1. To sell, in whole or in part, their net electricity production, the owners of installations subject to this royal decree must choose one of the following options: a) Transfer the electricity to the system through the transmission or distribution network, receiving a regulated tariff, which is the same for all scheduling periods, expressed in euro cents per kilowatt-hour. b) Sell the electricity in the electricity production market. In this case, the sale price of electricity will be the price determined in the organized market or the freely negotiated price agreed upon by the owner or representative of the installation, supplemented, where applicable, by a premium in euro cents per kilowatt-hour*" [**CL-0018**; **R-0084**].

Article 22.1 of RD 661/2007 refers to the "*period for maintaining regulated tariffs and premiums*" and provides that: *"1. Once 85 percent of the capacity target for a group or sub-group, as established in Articles 35 to 42 of this royal decree, has been reached, a resolution by the Secretary General of Energy will determine the maximum period during which installations registered in the Administrative Register of Special Regime Production Installations before the deadline will be entitled to the premium or, where applicable, the regulated tariff set in this royal decree for that group or sub-group. This period shall not be less than twelve months.*" [**CL-0018; R-0084**].

Arenales Solar PS, S.L. – Due Diligence – Executive Summary, Fröhlingsdorf Abogados, June 5, 2012 [**C-0031**].

RD 661/2007, art. 44 [**CL-0018**; **R-0084**]. (emphasis added)

540.

The Tribunal notes that the second paragraph of Article 44(3) of Royal Decree 661/2007 refers to installations whose commissioning certificates predate a certain date. It is worth emphasizing that Royal Decree 661/2007 made no reference to the pre-assignment register, which would be created later under Royal Decree-Law 6/2009. In any case, it is evident that the stability promised in the second paragraph of Article 44(3) of Royal Decree 661/2007 was limited exclusively to reviews of the regulated tariff and the upper and lower limits.

541.

In 2009, with the enactment of Royal Decree-Law 6/2009, the pre-assignment remuneration register was created. The rationale behind this mechanism is explained in the recitals of the Royal Decree-Law, which state:

*"The current regulation of the special regime does not establish adequate mechanisms to plan installations of this type of energy, nor to determine the amount and timing of remuneration premiums and, therefore, the impact on the costs allocated to the tariff system. **The measure provided in the Royal Decree-Law, by creating the Pre-Assignment Remuneration Register, allows for the correction of the situation described above from the very moment of its entry into force.** It will allow, **within the timeframes set by the Royal Decree-Law, to determine which installations are not only planned but also comply with the conditions to be executed and connected to the electricity system with all legal and regulatory requirements, the volume of power associated with them, and their impact on electricity tariff costs and schedule.** In any case, **the rights and expectations of the owners of the installations are respected**, with the necessary safeguards being established and a transitional regime being provided for adaptation*."1137

RDL 6/2009, Preamble [**CL-0020**; **R-0072**] (emphasis added).

542.

The text of the provision itself indicates that the pre-assignment register was intended to protect the rights and, specifically, the "*expectations*" of installation owners. This further confirms that pre-assignment registration was capable of generating expectations.

543.

Nonetheless, registration in the pre-assignment register, under the terms of RDL 6/2009 of April 30, did not yet grant a definitive right to the economic regime of RD 661/2007. In accordance with Article 4(2) of RDL 6/2009: "*Registration in the Pre-Assignment Register for remuneration shall be a necessary condition for the granting of the right to the economic regime established in Royal Decree 661/2007, of May 25, regulating the production of electricity under the special regime*."1138 Along the same lines, the Council of Ministers' Agreement of November 13, 2009 emphasized that Article 4 of Royal Decree-Law 6/2009 "*creates an administrative Pre-Assignment Remuneration Register for electricity production installations and establishes that registration therein shall be a **necessary condition for receiving the economic regime associated with the special regime***."1139 The same Agreement underscored the importance of definitive registration (Section IV). Article 4(8) of Royal Decree-Law 6/2009 further clarified that: *"[I]nstallations registered in the Pre-Assignment Remuneration Register shall have a maximum period of thirty-six months from the date of notification to be definitively registered in the Administrative Register of Electricity Production Installations under the competent authority and to commence energy sales. **Otherwise, they shall lose the economic right associated with inclusion in the Pre-Assignment Remuneration Register***."1140

RDL 6/2009, art. 4(2) [**CL-0020**; **R-0072**].

RDL 6/2009, art. 4(8) [**CL-0020**; **R-0072**]. (emphasis added).

(iv) Conclusion on the scope of Steag's legitimate expectation
--------------------------------------------------------------

593.

After analyzing RD 661/2007, RDL 6/2009, RD 1614/2010, and RDL 1/2012 together, the Tribunal has found that the registration resolution of December 2009, interpreted in light of RDL 6/2009 and considering the stability commitment established in Article 4 of RD 1614/2010, which was also linked to that resolution, was capable of generating a legitimate expectation of stability concerning certain elements of the economic regime applicable to Arenales Solar.

594.

This expectation of stability does not translate into a "*freeze*" of the entirety of RD 661/2007 with respect to Arenales Solar. Spain defined, within the cited regulations, the elements that constituted a reasonable return, and Steag obtained from Spain an administrative act of a specific and concrete nature that established the components of reasonable return, provided that certain conditions were met. The expectation that Steag could objectively have and did have as of June 8, 2012, was that: The reasonable return determined by Spain at that time would be upheld; The tariffs, premiums, and upper and lower limits referenced in RD 1614/2010—a regulation that the Claimant itself considers fundamental to its expectations — would remain unchanged. This stability would extend for the plant's useful life, provided that the requirement of definitive registration before January 1, 2014, was met — which it was.

*d) Frustration of Steag's Legitimate Expectations*
---------------------------------------------------

595.

The Claimant has successfully demonstrated that it had an expectation of stability regarding the elements of premium, tariff, and upper and lower limits under the economic regime applicable to the Arenales Solar plant throughout the installation's useful life. Steag alleges that this expectation was frustrated by the gradual adoption of the NRR. Specifically, the Claimant argues that, after making the investment, "*the Spanish Government, under the presidency of Mr. Rajoy Brey, introduced, retroactively, a series of changes to the regime applicable to solar thermal power plants (which, of course, includes Arenales Solar) on the grounds that this would eliminate the Spanish tariff deficit."*1208

626.

The Tribunal has thoroughly considered the legal framework that, according to the Claimant, frustrated its legitimate expectations. It is undeniable that Spain altered the tariffs, premiums, and upper/lower limits established under RD 661/2007 and RD 1614/2010. The NRR did not merely introduce modifications to the economic framework for facilities registered in the Pre-Assignment Register and RAIPRE. Instead, it fundamentally transformed the remuneration system, determining returns based on entirely new parameters, such as the "*efficient installation*" concept and a return model based on a "*standard facility*", whose characteristics were solely determined by the Spanish State at its discretion.

627.

As previously stated, on June 8, 2012, Steag had a legitimate expectation that, provided it completed definitive registration before January 1, 2014, it would be entitled to benefit from the tariffs, premiums, and upper/lower limits for the entire useful life of the Arenales Solar installation. Spain radically altered the fundamental elements of the remuneration framework it had committed to maintaining for installations registered under the Pre-Assignment Register. Spain thus undermined the very expectation it had created regarding the applicable remuneration regime if the investor complied with the pre-assignment registration requirement, which in Steag's case was formalized through an individual and specific administrative act.

628.

Spain's defense has focused on the rationale behind the reforms. 630.

This Tribunal does not question the legitimacy of Spain's objectives in adjusting the economic regime for electricity production facilities as part of its energy policy. The Tribunal also does not need to assess whether the NRR was the best regulatory option available to Spain or whether it was successful in resolving the tariff deficit.1260 However, the Tribunal emphasizes that justifying a radical change in the remuneration framework for a protected investment cannot rely solely on invoking public policy objectives, no matter how laudable or important they may be to the economy. This is especially true when the State has made a specific commitment to a foreign investor, creating legitimate expectations that directly motivated a particular investment.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 435, 447 et seq.

631.

This arbitration does not concern an abstract question of whether the SEE's regulatory framework could be modified. The Claimant has explained that its expectation was not that the regulatory framework would remain entirely immutable.1261 For the Tribunal, the FET standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT does not prevent Spain from exercising its regulatory authority over the electricity sector. This case does not challenge Spain's *ius variandi* (right to modify regulations). States may modify their legislation, and regulatory changes may naturally have a negative impact on protected investments.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 349, et seq. and 373.

632.

Nonetheless, the ECT requires the State to provide a stable and transparent legal framework for covered investments. Article 10(1) of the ECT explicitly refers to the objective of creating "*stable, equitable, favorable, and transparent conditions for investors of other Contracting Parties to make investments in its territory.*" This objective aligns with the European Energy Charter, which is explicitly referenced in Article 2 of the ECT. Legitimate Expectations and the State's Obligations Likewise, among the "*objectives*" listed in Title I of the ECT, reference is made to "*the development of stable and transparent legal frameworks that create conditions for the development of energy resources.*"

633.

Article 10(1) of the ECT does not eliminate the State's regulatory power but rather establishes certain limits on its exercise, protecting investors from changes to essential elements of the regulatory framework that motivated their investment.1262

See *Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 530-532 [**CL-0130**]; *OperaFund Eco-Invest SICAV PLC y Schwab Holding AG v. Kingdom of Spain*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/15/36 (September 6, 2019), ¶ 508, 509 [**CL-0162**].

634.

In particular, when the State has created a legitimate expectation, and even more so when it has done so through a specific and concrete act, it cannot frustrate that expectation without offering reasonable compensation to the affected party. As the tribunal stated in *Cube Infrastructure v. Spain*, "*A State cannot induce an investor to make an investment by generating legitimate expectations, only to later disregard the commitments that created those expectations*."1263 The State must respect specific commitments it has made, and in any case, it must exercise its *ius variandi* in a proportionate manner, taking into account the interests of affected parties.1264 In this case, Spain was entitled to exercise its regulatory power, but it was also obliged to respect the expectation it had created for Steag at the time of investment, which specifically protected tariffs, premiums, and upper/lower limits as established under Article 4 of RD 1614/2010.

*Charanne BV et al. v. Kingdom of Spain*, Final Award, SCC Case No. V 062/2012 (January 21, 2016), ¶ 486 [**RL-0049**].

3. Tribunal's Analysis

676.

The Tribunal has found that Spain violated the FET standard through certain measures included in the NRR, specifically: ***(i)*** The adjustment of the regulated tariff based on the core CPI; ***(ii)*** The transition to a fixed tariff by reducing the "pool + premium" option to zero; and ***(iii)*** The introduction of a new remuneration scheme based on the concept of a "*standard installation*." With respect to these measures, the Tribunal deems it unnecessary to analyze whether they also violate Article 13 of the ECT, as they already constitute violations of the FET standard.

677.

A violation of Article 13 of the ECT would only be relevant if the measures that did not breach the FET standard were found to have expropriatory effects. There are two such measures: The 7% tax on energy production, introduced by Law 15/2012. The Tribunal found that the claim regarding its alleged expropriatory nature is inadmissible, as Steag did not comply with the requirement under Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT.

678.

The second measure for which no violation of the FET standard was found is the elimination of the possibility of selling gas-generated electricity under the regulated tariff. The Tribunal finds that the Claimant failed to present a clear argument regarding the expropriatory nature of this measure. Moreover, there is no evidence that it had an acquired right to the regulated tariff for gas-generated electricity.

679.

Even if these issues were disregarded, the Tribunal notes that the Claimant's central argument is that: "*Spain's measures have an effect equivalent to expropriation: the New Regulatory Regime has eliminated the value of Steag's investment in Arenales Solar. **B. Tribunal's Analysis**
--------------------------

1. General parameters for determining compensable loss
------------------------------------------------------

743.

The Tribunal has found that the Respondent violated the FET standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT by frustrating the legitimate and objective expectations of the Claimant at the time of investment, which occurred on June 8, 2012. These expectations extended beyond a reasonable return. Steag expected that the tariffs, premiums, and upper and lower limits referred to in RD 1614/2010 would be maintained. This stability would have lasted for the useful life of the plant, provided that the final registration requirement before January 1, 2014 was met, which it was.

744.

The frustration of Steag's legitimate expectations at the time of investment constitutes a violation of the FET standard, which, by engaging Spain's international responsibility, requires full reparation for the damages caused by the internationally wrongful act.

745.

The Tribunal begins by noting that, as other tribunals have explained, Article 10 of the ECT does not establish a specific compensation standard applicable when a breach of its obligations occurs.1575 The Tribunal considers that, in this context, the general rule under Article 31 of the Articles on State Responsibility applies, which states:

"Article 31. Reparation.

1. The responsible State is under an obligation to make full reparation for the injury caused by the internationally wrongful act.

2. Injury includes any damage, whether material or moral, caused by the internationally wrongful act of a State."

See *Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 659 [**CL-0130**].

746.

For reparation purposes, the general principles developed by the PCIJ in its decision in the *Chorzów* Factory case of September 13, 1928, apply:

"The essential principle contained in the actual notion of an illegal act — a principle which seems to be established by international practice and, in particular, by the decisions of arbitral tribunals — is that reparation must, as far as possible, wipe out all the consequences of the unlawful act and restore the situation which would, in all probability, have existed if that act had not been committed. Restitution in kind or, if this is not possible, payment of a sum corresponding to the value which a restitution in kind would bear; the award, if need be, of damages for loss sustained which would not be covered by restitution in kind or payment in place of it — such are the principles which should serve to determine the amount of compensation due for an act contrary to international law."1576

Translation of the Tribunal. Original text: "*The essential principle contained in the actual notion of an illegal act – a principle which seems to be established by international practice and in particular by the decisions of arbitral tribunals – is that reparation must, as far as possible, wipe out all the consequences of the illegal act and re-establish the situation which would, in all probability, have existed if that act had not been committed. Restitution in kind, or, if this is not possible, payment of a sum corresponding to the value which a restitution in kind would bear; the award, if need be, of damages for loss sustained which would not be covered by restitution in kind or payment in place of it-such are the principles which should serve to determine the amount of compensation due for an act contrary to international law*" (CPJI, Series A, No. 17, p. 47).

747.

The burden of proving the damage rests on the Claimant.1577 In light of how the Parties have presented their arguments regarding Steag's damages and the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal considers that several relevant factors must be taken into account when determining the compensable harm: **(2)** the internationally wrongful measures attributable to Spain that are relevant to the damages analysis; **(3)** the date from which damages should be calculated; **(4)** Steag's contribution to the harm; **(5)** the effects of the 2020 divestment transaction; **(6)** the useful life of the Arenales Solar plant; **(7)** the tax gross-up; and **(8)** the methodology for calculating the compensable loss.

2. Internationally wrongful measures attributable to Spain relevant to the damages analysis
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

748.

The internationally wrongful conduct of the State must be the proximate and factual cause of the damage, in accordance with Article 31 of the Articles on State Responsibility.1578 The Tribunal has found that the Respondent violated the FET standard under Article 10(1) of the ECT through the implementation of the NRR, particularly by: (***i***) adjusting the regulated tariff based on the underlying CPI; (***ii***) transitioning to a fixed tariff by reducing to zero the option of the premium plus pool; and (***iii***) introducing a new remuneration regime based on the assumption of a "*standard facility*."1579

*Ioan Micula et al. v. Romania*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/05/20 (December 11, 2013), ¶ 923 [**RL-0081**].

Paragraph 639 *above*

749.

These measures do not include the TVPEE, which was not part of the Tribunal's merits analysis. The reasons for excluding the TVPEE are twofold. First, taking into account that the TVPEE is a "tax measure" under the parameters of Article 21(7)(a) of the ECT, the Tribunal concluded that it lacks jurisdiction over the alleged violation of Article 10(1) of the ECT due to the introduction of the TVPEE through Law 15/2012. Second, the Tribunal found that the claim regarding the alleged expropriatory effects of the TVPEE is inadmissible for failure to meet the requirement set forth in Article 21(5)(b) of the ECT. In light of the foregoing, any damages resulting from the TVPEE must be excluded from the determination of the compensable loss.

750.

The damages analysis also excludes the elimination of the possibility of selling gas-generated electricity under the regulated tariff. In its merits analysis, the Tribunal did not find that Spain had violated Articles 10(1) or 13 of the ECT through this measure.

751.

In this context, the Tribunal reiterates that only those damages that Steag has suffered as a consequence of Spain's internationally wrongful conduct are compensable. Additionally, as will be explained in the next section, damages are calculated from the moment this change had an economic impact on Arenales Solar. According to the Claimant, this moment corresponds to June 20, 2014.1580
