3. Date from Which Damages Should Be Calculated
-----------------------------------------------

752.

The Tribunal must determine the date that should be used as the reference for the quantum assessment of the compensable damage. The general rule, as stated by other tribunals, is that damages are calculated from the date of the injury resulting from the internationally wrongful act.1581 When the treaty violation results from multiple successive measures, the reference date for the quantum assessment of the damage is typically the date on which all relevant events have concluded, leading to an irreversible economic impact on the investment.1582

*Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 581 [**CL-0130**].

*Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 581 [**CL-0130**].

753.

Based on these parameters, the Tribunal finds that the amount of the compensable loss must be calculated from the moment Spain's internationally wrongful conduct had an economic impact on the Arenales Solar project. The Claimant identifies this date as June 20, 2014, when "*Spain definitively set the remuneration that would apply to the Plant as a result of the regulatory changes*."1583 In the Brattle Damages Report, the experts indicate that "*[S]teag's legal advisors instructed us to measure the present value of damages as of June 20, 2014, when Spain finally defined the applicable tariffs for Steag's solar thermal plant*."1584

Memorial of Claim, ¶ 271.

Claimant - Brattle Report on Damages, ¶ 11.

754.

This date coincides with the publication in the Official State Gazette of Ministerial Order IET/1045/2014, "*approving the remuneration parameters for standard facilities applicable to certain electricity production facilities based on renewable energy sources, cogeneration, and waste*."1585 As stated in paragraph 161 above, Ministerial Order IET/1045/2014 set the reasonable return rate applicable to facilities that existed prior to the entry into force of RDL 9/2013 at 7.398%.

Ministerial Order IET/1045/2014, of June 16, 2014, approving the remuneration parameters for standard installations applicable to certain electricity production installations from renewable energy sources, cogeneration, and waste ("**Ministerial Order IET/1045/2014**") [**CL-0028**].

755.

The Tribunal agrees with the Claimant that the moment when Steag's investment suffered an irreversible economic harm was June 20, 2014. Ministerial Order IET/1045/2014 represents the culmination of the series of measures that led to the violation of the FET standard. It was at that moment, and not before, that the parameters of the NRR were concretely defined. Conducting an assessment prior to June 20, 2014, would require resorting to an artificial and retrospective valuation method. The economic effects of the NRR did not occur, nor were they determinable in a precise and certain manner, before that date.

756.

For these reasons, the Tribunal will set June 20, 2014, as the date from which the compensable loss should be calculated.

4. Steag's Contribution to the Loss
-----------------------------------

757.

The Tribunal has determined that Steag's investment date is June 8, 2012, at which time there was an expectation that Arenales Solar would retain the tariffs, premiums, and the upper and lower limits referred to in RD 1614/2010, for the facility's useful life.

758.

The Parties have explained that, after June 8, 2012, Steag made multiple capital injections, which continued even during 2013 and 2014.1586 These capital injections occurred even after the measures comprising the NRR had begun to be gradually adopted.

759.

The Tribunal notes that, according to the Claimant's narrative, the Arenales Solar project lost its economic attractiveness with the introduction of the NRR.1587 This raises the question of whether, once the measures had been announced or adopted, the Claimant continued making significant capital injections because it had no alternative under the contracts it had signed, or whether it knowingly assumed a risk despite having options to mitigate or eliminate the potential loss caused by the measures it now challenges. In other words, the question is whether Steag's conduct constitutes a contributing cause to the loss it claims to have suffered.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 435.

760.

The Tribunal begins by noting that the conduct of the party claiming to have suffered a loss, particularly its contribution to the damage or loss, is a widely recognized element in the analysis and quantification of compensable loss.1588 This follows from Article 39 of the Articles on State Responsibility, which states:

"Article 39. Contribution to the loss. In determining reparation, account shall be taken of the contribution to the loss by willful or negligent action or omission of the injured State or of any person or entity in relation to whom reparation is sought."

See *MTD Equity Sdn. Bhd. and MTD Chile S.A. v. Republic of Chile*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/01/7 (May 25, 2004), ¶¶ 242, 243 [**CL-0039**].

761.

As the tribunal in *Gemplus v. Mexico* stated:

"Article 39 of the ILC Articles on State Responsibility excludes full or partial recovery when, through the intentional or negligent act or omission of the claimant State or person, that State or person has contributed to the loss for which it seeks reparation from the respondent State."1589

Translation of the Tribunal. Original text: "*Article 39 of the ILC's Articles on State Responsibility precludes full or any recovery, where, through the willful or negligent act or omission of the claimant state or person, that state or person has contributed to the injury for which reparation is sought from the respondent state*". *Gemplus S.A. et al. v. United Mexican States,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB(AF)/04/3 and ARB(AF)/04/4 (June 16, 2010), ¶ 11.12 [**RL-0075**].

Response to Spain's Comments on the Fronterasol and Steag Transaction in Arenales Solar PS, S.L., February 20, 2020, ¶ 14. (emphasis added).

790.

This is particularly significant given that, according to the Claimant, the approval of RDL 17/2019 of November 22, 2019, continued to affect its contractual position.1640 In this context, Steag refers to "*the greater damages that Arenales would suffer due to the lower remuneration it will receive as a result of this new modification of the New Regulatory Regime*."1641

Steag's Comments on the Lack of Relationship Between the Transaction and Clause 2.1.6.(c) of the Shareholders' Commitment Agreement, March 5, 2020, ¶ 11, 12.

Steag's Comments on the Lack of Relationship Between the Transaction and Clause 2.1.6.(c) of the Shareholders' Commitment Agreement, March 5, 2020, ¶ 12.

791.

In other words, according to Steag's own account, its situation in 2020 was worse than it was between 2013 and 2014. However, despite this, its stake still retained an "*implicit value*" for which another investor was willing to pay compensation. Even more so, before the adoption of RDL 17/2019, it should have been possible to negotiate an exit from the project. If Steag did not find this course of action convenient and did not even attempt to initiate such negotiations at that time, it cannot now expect Spain to bear the consequences of its decision.

792.

The Tribunal is not convinced that the project finance documents constituted, as the Claimant asserts, a kind of "*straitjacket*" from which it was impossible to escape. First, as the Claimant itself affirmed when discussing the sale of its stake in Arenales Solar, Steag's contractual position had value. Second, there is no evidence that the Claimant, either directly or with the cooperation of its partners, attempted to renegotiate or restructure the project to reduce the impact on Arenales Solar. Neither the contractual clauses, the financing structure, nor the project's expected cash flow prevented the Claimant from diligently seeking a revision of the economic model or adjusting cash flows to mitigate the impact of the measures. No project finance arrangement is immutable, and they are generally adjustable when conditions affecting cash flow arise. However, the Tribunal has not been informed of any efforts by the Claimant to renegotiate agreements or implement measures that would have mitigated or eliminated the impact on the project's structure. The Respondent should not have to bear the full consequences of the Claimant's financing structure when the latter failed to make the necessary efforts to negotiate a modification.

793.

Even if one accepts that the 2012 contracts were indeed a rigid "*straitjacket*," forcing Steag to continue making capital contributions with little to no room for negotiation, the fact remains that these contracts were freely negotiated by Steag. As noted above, on July 31, 2012, in Clause 3.4 of the Partial Subrogation Agreement and Amendment to the Investment Agreement between the original investors and STEAG 1 and STEAG,1642 Steag expressly acknowledged the existence of an economic crisis and the risk that measures could be adopted that would affect the Arenales Solar project. Aware of this risk, it explicitly waived the right to invoke it as a reason to withdraw from the negotiations. If the contracts signed at the end of 2012 genuinely did not allow for Steag's unilateral exit and forced it to continue injecting funds, despite its investment allegedly becoming "*completely worthless*,"1643 then the responsibility for that structure rests with Steag.

Partial Subrogation Agreement and Amendment to the Investment Agreement between the original investors and STEAG 1 and STEAG, dated July 31, 2012, clause 3.4 [**C-0019**].

Memorial of Claim, ¶ 268.

794.

The Tribunal finds that while Spain breached the FET standard by introducing a regulatory regime radically different from the RRO — frustrating the expectations that Spain itself had created for Steag at the time of its investment — the financing structure that Steag negotiated also played a role in the damage suffered. Steag was part of ongoing negotiations after the investment date, during which the project's financing was structured. Due to the way it structured the project finance, Steag made multiple capital injections between the second half of 2012 and 2014, even when Spain's measures had already been announced or implemented. The Tribunal cannot overlook the fact that part of the loss the Claimant alleges to have suffered resulted from how Steag handled the successive negotiations of the project finance.

795.

The consequence of Steag's contribution to the loss is a reduction in the amount of compensation. The Tribunal enjoys broad discretion in determining the percentage by which the compensation is reduced.1644 In other cases, reductions have been, for example, 25%1645 or 50%.1646

*Occidental Petroleum Corporation and Occidental Exploration and Production Company v. Republic of Ecuador*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/06/11 (October 5, 2012), ¶ 670 [**CL-0040**].

*Occidental Petroleum Corporation and Occidental Exploration and Production Company v. Republic of Ecuador*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/06/11 (October 5, 2012), ¶ 687 [**CL-0040**].

*MTD Equity Sdn. Bhd. and MTD Chile S.A. v. Republic of Chile*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/01/7 (May 25, 2004), ¶ 243 [**CL-0039**].

796.

The Tribunal, having analyzed all the circumstances of the case and within the scope of its discretion, finds that Steag's contribution to the injury can be quantified at 25%. This percentage reflects Steag's factual partial contribution to the total amount of the damage while also recognizing the severity of Spain's conduct as the primary cause of the damage suffered. Consequently, once the total amount of damages suffered by the investor is determined, the Tribunal will proceed to reduce the compensable amount in the indicated proportion.

5. Impact of the 2020 Divestment
--------------------------------

797.

The Tribunal must take into account Steag's sale of its stake in Arenales Solar, which, according to the Claimant, took place in February 2020.1647 In its Reply Memorial, Steag asserted that, as a result of Spain's actions: "*[T]he plant's operating profit is substantially reduced, preventing the distribution of free cash flows to shareholders and preventing the Claimant from recovering its investment. The renegotiation of Arenales Solar's shareholders with the Financial Entities becomes difficult, preventing an extension of the repayment period for loans granted for the Plant's construction or a reduction in the applicable interest rate, which would allow the release of sufficient cash flows to provide remuneration to Arenales Solar's shareholders. **The liquidity of Steag's position in Arenales Solar is reduced, its fair market value is reduced to EUR 0 under a discounted cash flow analysis, and thus, Steag is prevented from limiting its losses by selling its position to a potential investor***.*"*1648

Communication regarding the transfer of STEAG GmbH's position in Arenales Solar PS, S.L. to Fronterasol, B.V., February 4, 2020, ¶¶ 2, 3.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 504 (emphasis added). The Tribunal notes that this point is presented in a section related to the expropriation claim.

798.

Given the way damages were alleged and Steag's claim that its stake's market value was EUR 0, the Tribunal cannot ignore that the investor was able to sell its stake in Arenales Solar in the February 2020 transaction,1649 obtaining — as the Claimant itself admits — a sum of EUR 9,422,027 for it, which was paid by RREEF.1650 In one of its submissions on the matter, previously cited, the Claimant acknowledged that its contractual position "*had undeniable implicit value*" and that, moreover, "*Steag's contractual position allowed it to obtain a more beneficial compensation for its stake than it would normally have obtained*.*"*1651

Communication regarding the transfer of STEAG GmbH's stake in Arenales Solar PS, S.L. to Fronterasol, B.V., February 4, 2020, ¶¶ 2, 3.

Response to Spain's comments on the Fronterasol and Steag transaction in Arenales Solar PS, S.L., February 20, 2020, ¶ 4.

Response to Spain's Comments on the Fronterasol and Steag Transaction in Arenales Solar PS, S.L., February 20, 2020, ¶ 14.

799.

The Tribunal must therefore deduct from the compensable loss the amount Steag received for its stake in Arenales Solar.

6. Useful Life of the Arenales Solar Plant
------------------------------------------

800.

The Tribunal concurs with the Parties that the regulatory useful life of the plants is a key parameter for calculating the economic regime of the investments and, consequently, the damage. As indicated in the analysis of the Claimant's legitimate expectation, Steag could reasonably expect that the Arenales Solar facility would be subject to the economic regime under RD 661/2007 for the duration of its useful life.

801.

As a preliminary matter, the Tribunal notes that the Parties have discussed prior arbitral decisions, in which the useful life of the respective plants was found to be 25 years.1652 The Claimant has emphasized that this case is different from previous ones.1653 According to Steag, the key difference is that those awards did not establish proof that the respective plants would operate for more than 25 years, and they highlighted the high maintenance costs as a factor to consider.1654

Hearing, Day 1, 87:19-22 (Díaz de la Cruz); 175:1-3 (Fernández Castilla).

Hearing, Day 1, 87:21-22 and 88:1-3 (Díaz de la Cruz)

Hearing, Day 1, 180:14-22 and 181:1-3 (Fernández Castilla). See Reports, Professor Servert [**JSRC-16** and **JSRC-17**].

802.

The Tribunal agrees with Steag that each case is unique. The useful life of Arenales Solar for the purposes of damage calculation must be estimated based on the available data for that specific plant, considering how the investment was structured.

803.

The Parties and their experts disagree on the useful life of the Arenales Solar Plant, which must be taken into account for the damage calculation. The estimates presented to the Tribunal range from 20 to 40 years. For instance, the Brattle Report of May 26, 2017, suggests that the useful life of the Arenales Solar Plant would reach 40 years.1655 In this regard, the experts explain:

"Our analysis assumes that *Arenales* could operate for 40 years without requiring significant investments. The RRO provided incentives for continued operation beyond 25 years, as economic support decreased by a relatively modest 20% after that point. The sharp decline in projected revenues after 2038 in the actual scenario reflects the effective closure of *Arenales*."1656

Economic Damages Suffered by Steag (Brattle), ¶¶ 69, 70, and No. 57.

Economic Damages Suffered by Steag (Brattle), ¶ 69 (footnote omitted).

804.

The Tribunal does not find that the useful life of the Arenales Solar plant is 40 years, not even from a technical perspective. The Tribunal has carefully considered the arguments put forward by Mr. Schneider to justify the calculation of a 40-year useful life. However, the Tribunal is not convinced that a 40-year useful life can be considered for the purposes of damage calculation. First, in the hearing, Mr. Schneider himself explained that his calculation was based on the plant's cycles, which is a variable criterion. In his own words: "*A cycle could last 1 hour or could also last 3 days, for example*."1657 Furthermore, Mr. Servet emphasized that, even from a technical perspective, it has not been proven that the Arenales Solar Plant will operate for 40 years. Mr. Servet pointed out that: "*While cycles are important, they are not the only determining factor for the life of equipment*. *The operating temperature, corrosion, normal wear and tear, and — as my colleague mentioned — how start-up and shutdown cycles are conducted, all play a very important role*."1658 Considering certain uncertainties and technical defects, Servet even suggests a useful life of only 20 years.1659 His conclusion was: "*The plant was designed for 25 years, and it should have lasted 25 years, but with all the engineering problems — with equipment, construction, operation, and maintenance — the best estimate I can give is 20 years*. *This plant has not been properly operated, maintained, or even built correctly, and that will have consequences*."1660

Hearing, Day 3, 792: 11-12 (Schneider).

Hearing, Day 3, 864:5-11 (Servet).

Hearing, Day 3, 870:13-15; 873:6-11; 878:1-4; 884:22 and 885:1-7 (Servet).

Hearing, Day 3, 884:22 y 885:1-7 (Servet).

805.

The Tribunal finds that, although the experts disagree on the number of years the Arenales Solar Plant will operate from a technical standpoint, there is no doubt that the plant was designed to operate for 25 years.1661 Additionally, even if the plant were technically capable of operating for a longer period, the fixed tariff was granted for 25 years. Moreover, the Tribunal agrees with the Respondent that the Arenales Solar Plant was designed to have a useful life of 25 years.1662

Hearing, Day 3, 855:18-22 (Servet) ("The design criterion is what this plant was designed for, for how many years, and in that I believe both experts agree: the design criterion is 25 years, the quality of design.") See also Hearing, Day 3, 863:1-10 (Servet).

Post-Hearing Brief - First Round (Spain), ¶ 262.

806.

For damage calculation purposes, a 25-year useful life is appropriate not only because it aligns with the plant's design, but also because it was the reference period consistently used for economic and financial calculations regarding the project. In this regard, the Accuracy report is correct when, challenging the starting point of the Brattle Report, it explains that a 25-year useful life for the plants would be a "*conservative figure*," far more appropriate than 40 years.1663 Accuracy argues that there is no justification for assuming a 40-year useful life assuming the RRO remained in place (But for scenario).1664 Accuracy draws attention to several factual element:1665

(i) According to Arenales' annual accounts, the depreciation calculation assumed a 25-year useful life.1666 Likewise, the EPC contract was based on a 25-year useful life.1667

(ii) Something similar occurred with the investment report, as the IRR of the project was based on a useful life calculated between 20 and 25 years.1668

(iii) A 2012 technical report, cited in Arenales Solar's annual accounts, also indicated a useful life of 25 years.1669 The excerpt from the annual accounts states: "*The company depreciates its fixed assets from the date of commissioning using the straight-line method, distributing the cost of the assets over the estimated useful life — which, according to a technical study conducted by an independent expert in 2012, amounts to 25 years for all assets*."1670

(iv) Accuracy considers a 25-year useful life for the Arenales Plant in both the actual and but for scenarios, as the most reasonable maximum horizon.1671 In the actual scenario, the rate of return was calculated at 7.398% pre-tax, the rate established in RDL 9/2013, applied over a 25-year useful life.

First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim (Accuracy), ¶ 145(c).

First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim (Accuracy), ¶ 145(c).

First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim (Accuracy), ¶ 145(c).

Arenales' Annual Accounts [**BQR-03**].

EPC Contract for the Construction of the Plant with Ecolaire España S.A., dated July 28, 2011, p. 18 [**C-0013**].

Project Presentation by Directors to the Board of Directors, p. 21 [**C-0018**].

Arenales' Annual Accounts [**BQR-03**].

Arenales' Annual Accounts [**BQR-03**].

First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim (Accuracy), ¶ 26.

807.

In the hearing, this consistent reference to a 25-year useful life was justified by the difference between the "*technical*" and "*economic*" useful life of Arenales Solar. As Mr. Ponce de León stated: *"**We have a 25-year tariff, and as of today, we cannot amortize the asset beyond that tariff**, which is our justification for tax purposes, as recognized by Hacienda (Spanish tax authorities), for the plant's useful life. Because technical useful life is one thing, but economic useful life is another. Obviously, if we don't have a tariff that can support the costs at that time, we won't be able to keep operating the plant. That's why we are accounting for and amortizing it fiscally over 25 years*.*"*1672 In other words, even the Claimant never assumed that the asset would be amortized over 40 years.

Hearing, Day 1, 349:6-18 (Ponce de León) (emphasis added).

808.

For this Tribunal, it is essential that even the Claimant did not expect the RRO remuneration to extend beyond 25 years. This arbitration concerns the transition from the RRO to the NRR and its effects on Steag's investment.1673 In the hearing, it became clear that Steag never expected, based on the legislation in force in Spain at the time of its investment, to receive remuneration under the RRO for more than 25 years. According to Mr. Rumstadt's statement regarding the legal due diligence: "*I was told that this was a solid norm with legal standing that would provide us with significant comfort for an investment that would last for 25 years, during which we would receive the tariff as proposed in the three aforementioned decrees*.*"*1674 Mr. Rumstadt also explained that *"it is typical to see these projects structured for a 20-year term, and in this case, it was an advantage for us to expect a 25-year term for this feed-in tariff*."1675 The feed-in tariff was calculated based on 25 years.1676

In the case of the NRR, Article 5 of Order IET/1045/2014 [**R-0229**] determines the regulatory useful life of standard installations in a table, with values ranging from 20 to 30 years. For most types, the regulatory life is 25 years.

Hearing, Day 1, 299:4-14 (Rumstadt).

Hearing, Day 1, 305:5-13 (Rumstadt).

Hearing, Day 1, 322:13-22 and 323:1-2 (Rumstadt).

809.

Likewise, in his witness testimony, Mr. Daniel Voswinkel admitted that, under the RRO, the internal rate of return for Arenales Solar was calculated based on an assumed useful life of 25 years:

"Investment decisions within STEAG are based on the achievable internal rate of return, using the discounted cash flow calculation method. As a general internal practice at STEAG, projects are initially calculated based on a conservative assumption of a 20-year lifespan, ignoring the actual technical and economic life of a power plant. **However, the Original Regulatory Regime was fully applicable during the first 25 years of operation. We considered this relevant. The internal rate of return calculated for the Arenales Project was based on a 25-year lifespan,** and the regulated tariff with a premium led to an internal rate of return of 12.5%. Additionally, Spain's original commitment to providing financial support for gas combustion up to 15% of production was taken into account. STEAG engineers informed me that the technical lifespan of the Arenales Plant is estimated to be around 40 years. The remaining 15 years are considered a supplement to the originally projected IRR."1677

Witness Statement of Mr. Daniel Voswinkel, dated May 10, 2018, ¶ 31 (emphasis added).

810.

For the foregoing reasons, the Tribunal finds that it has not been proven that the Arenales Solar plant has a useful life of 40 years. What is established, however, is that the investment was projected based on a useful life of 25 years. The Tribunal therefore concludes that, for the purposes of determining the compensable loss, a useful life of 25 years should be used as the basis.

7. The Tax Gross-Up
-------------------

811.

The Tribunal has considered the Claimant's argument regarding the alleged damages resulting from the "*tax impact of the award payment*."1678 The core of the Claimant's argument is that "*[…] based on the principle of full compensation for the losses and damages suffered by Steag, receiving cash flows through dividends and loan amortization is not the same as receiving them through a potential award granting compensation*."1679 According to the Claimant, *"[w]hile the first option receives a specific tax treatment, the second is subject to a different taxation*."1680 The State has opposed this claim and has contested the investor's reasoning.1681

Post-Hearing Brief - First Round (Steag), ¶¶ 191, et seq.

Post-Hearing Brief - First Round (Steag), ¶ 192.

Post-Hearing Brief - First Round (Steag), ¶ 192.

Post-Hearing Brief - Second Round (Steag), ¶¶ 172, 175.

812.

The Tribunal notes that the Parties have supported their positions on this issue with two reports. Steag bases its claim on a report by Ernst & Young GmbH (Exhibit **BQR-056**).1682 According to the Claimant, "*income received through dividends distributed by Arenales Solar PS, S.L. would have been taxed at an effective rate of 1.631%. However, in the real scenario, the income that might be received as a result of a favorable award for Steag would be fully taxed, resulting in an effective tax rate of 32.625%*.*"*1683

Post-Hearing Brief - First Round (Steag), ¶ 191.

Post-Hearing Brief - First Round (Steag), ¶ 217.

813.

In turn, Spain opposes the investor's conclusions based on a report prepared by the firm Noerr (Exhibit **ACQ-0062**). Based on that report, the State argues that "*[t]he conclusion that the 'But for' scenario would be equal to the 'Actual' scenario, even assuming (but not accepting, as STEAG suggests) that any potential compensation awarded by the Tribunal would be taxed as ordinary income, is incorrect*."1684 According to the State, there are two possible scenarios:

"(i) Either the compensation is considered a payment equivalent to a dividend (which it is from an economic perspective), in which case a "tax gross-up" would automatically not apply, because the "Actual" and "But for" scenarios would be treated the same from a tax perspective; or (ii) it is considered ordinary income, subject to standard tax regulations, in which case we need to analyze what the tax treatment of dividends would have been in the 'But for' scenario, as Noerr did in its report. As the Tribunal may recall, Noerr concluded that, due to certain tax rules, dividends (in the 'But for' scenario) would not benefit from a tax exemption and would therefore be taxed as ordinary income."1685

Post-Hearing Brief - Second Round (Steag), ¶ 162.

Post-Hearing Brief - Second Round (Steag), ¶ 161.

814.

The Tribunal observes that the burden of proving the damage rests with Steag.1686 This burden applies not only to proving the existence of damage but also to quantifying it. It is the Claimant's responsibility to demonstrate the alleged loss resulting from the "*tax impact of the award payment*" that would, in its view, justify a "*tax gross-up*."

*Gemplus S.A. et al. v. United Mexican States*, Award, ICSID Case No. ARB(AF)/04/3 and ARB(AF)/04/4 (June 16, 2010), ¶¶ 12-56, 13-80, and 13-81 [**RL-0075**].

815.

The Tribunal finds that Spain has not met this burden. Having carefully considered the Parties' arguments and reviewed the submitted reports, the Tribunal concludes that the loss alleged by Steag is uncertain. The investor's argument is based on contingent hypotheses and interpretations of the applicable tax laws that are not free from controversy, as revealed by the Noerr Report. According to that report, "*[t]here is no case law on the tax treatment in Germany of an award issued under the Energy Charter Treaty ("ECT") such as the present case*."1687 Spain is therefore correct in arguing that "*there is legal uncertainty that could be resolved in opposing directions by future rulings of the German tax courts*."1688

Noerr Report [**ACQ-0062**], pp. 4, 9.

Post-Hearing Brief - Second Round (Steag), ¶ 161.

816.

For the foregoing reasons, the Tribunal will not grant the tax gross-up requested by the Claimant.

8. Calculation of Compensable Loss: Methodology
-----------------------------------------------

817.

The Parties have extensively debated the most appropriate method for calculating damages. As previously explained, the Claimant presents its damage calculation based on the DCF method, comparing the actual cash flows of Arenales Solar (Actual scenario) with the hypothetical cash flows that would have been obtained in the absence of the NRR (But for scenario).1689 The Claimant arrives at a figure of EUR 79 million,1690 plus any amounts corresponding to capitalization of that amount until the date of the award, applicable taxes, and interest.1691

Memorial of Claim, ¶¶ 270 and 275.

Post-Hearing Brief - Second Round (Steag), ¶ 89; Additional Memorial, ¶ 201.

Memorial of Claim, ¶¶ 284 and 288.

818.

The Respondent argues that the damages claimed by Steag are "*completely and utterly speculative*."1692 According to the Respondent, the DCF method is not applicable to every factual situation and is inappropriate in the present case.1693 The Respondent goes further, claiming that "*Brattle's DCF is flawed, and once corrected, the result would be no damages*."1694 Spain asserts that "*the Claimant attempts to support its claim based on a simplistic comparison of scenarios ("Actual" and "But for"), assuming that the "Actual" scenario will remain unchanged for decades, while ignoring that the guiding principle of the system is the guaranteed reasonable return. Among other things, its models attempt to predict variables such as the pool price (which depends on oil prices) and energy demand. For all these reasons, projecting current parameters is hypothetical and unrealistic*."1695 Spain argues that damages should instead be assessed based on the Adjusted Book Value (ABV) method, which is structured around investment returns in a regulated market.1696 Under this method, the annual cash flow of an asset is determined based on the investment amount and the expected rate of return.1697

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 58. See also ¶ 1419.

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 61.

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 65. See also ¶¶ 1419, et seq.

Rejoinder and Reply on Jurisdiction, ¶¶ 1421. See also Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction and Counter-Memorial on the Merits, ¶ 1172.

First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim (Accuracy), ¶ 97.

First Economic Report on the Claimant and its Claim (Accuracy), ¶¶ 128, 129.

819.

The Tribunal begins by noting that, as other arbitral tribunals have stated, there are no correct or incorrect methods for calculating damages.1698 However, the DCF method is certainly one of the most frequently used methods.1699 This Tribunal is not called upon to determine, in the abstract, which method is most suitable for valuing investments but rather whether the DCF method used by the Claimant and its experts is appropriate for Steag's specific investment.

*Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 688 [**CL-0130**].

*Antin Infrastructure Services Luxembourg S.à.r.l. et al. v. Kingdom of Spain,* Award, ICSID Case No. ARB/13/31 (June 15, 2018), ¶¶ 688 [**CL-0130**].

820.

In the Tribunal's view, the use of the DCF method in this case is reasonable since it concerns an operational plant whose cash flows can be determined and projected. The Claimant is correct in explaining that the framework for establishing cash flows for the But for scenario is not speculative, as it is based on the criteria of the RRO, which guaranteed minimum cash flows.1700 The Tribunal finds that it is possible to construct a hypothetical scenario based on the RRO to objectively and determinately calculate the amount of compensable damage.

Reply on the Merits and Counter-Memorial on Objections to Jurisdiction, ¶ 515.

821.

While, in principle, the damage calculation based on the DCF method and the comparison between a hypothetical scenario (corresponding to the RRO) and the actual scenario (NRR) is logical and coherent with the circumstances of the case, this does not mean that the Tribunal agrees with the conclusions and scenarios presented in The Brattle Group's damages report. In particular, the Tribunal considers that the damage valuation must take into account and be based on the elements discussed in this decision, namely:

(i) The exclusion of the TVPEE from the set of measures considered for calculating compensable loss;

(ii) The exclusion of the possibility of selling gas-generated electricity at a regulated tariff from the set of measures considered for calculating compensable loss;

(iii) June 20, 2014, as the start date for calculating the loss;

(iv) The 25% reduction, representing the investor's contribution to the loss;

(v) The effects of the 2020 divestment; and

(vi) The useful life of the Arenales Solar plant, which, for the purposes of damage calculation, cannot be 40 years, as suggested in Brattle's But for scenario, but rather 25 years;

(vii) The exclusion of the tax gross-up requested by the Claimant.

822.

Since the damage calculations presented by the Parties to date have not accounted for all the elements outlined in paragraphs 820 and 821 above, the Tribunal requests that the Parties submit a mutually agreed-upon calculation that incorporates the criteria specified therein. If an agreement cannot be reached, the Parties must submit a document outlining the points of agreement and disagreement regarding the amount of compensable loss. Given the complexity of the case, the Tribunal considers a ninety (90)-day period from the notification of this decision to be a reasonable timeframe for this submission. Once this period has elapsed, the Tribunal will proceed to determine the amount of compensation and applicable interest.

**X. DECISION**
---------------

823.

For the reasons set forth above, the Tribunal rules as follows:

1. Unanimously, it declares that it lacks jurisdiction to adjudicate the dispute concerning the alleged violation of Article 10(1) of the ECT through the introduction of the TVPEE.

2. Unanimously, it declares the claim inadmissible regarding the alleged violation of Article 13 of the ECT through the introduction of the TVPEE.

3. Unanimously, it rejects all other Objections to Jurisdiction raised by the Respondent.

4. By majority decision, it declares that the Kingdom of Spain has breached the FET standard set forth in Article 10(1) of the ECT, as detailed in Section VIII(A)(3) of this Decision.

5. Unanimously, it dismisses all other claims by the Claimant regarding the alleged violations of Articles 10(1) and 13 of the ECT.

6. By majority, to order the Parties (a) to submit to the Tribunal within ninety (90) days from the date of notification of this decision a jointly agreed calculation of the amount of compensation, which must follow the methodology outlined in paragraph 820 of this decision and take into account the criteria indicated in paragraph 821 of the present decision; (b) in case of total or partial disagreement on the final value of the compensation, to submit to the Tribunal within the aforementioned ninety (90) days the points of agreement and disagreement regarding the calculation of compensation.

Date: October 8, 2020

Decisions.Title: Decision on the Stay of Enforcement of the Award
Decisions.Content:
Decision on the Stay of Enforcement of the Award
------------------------------------------------

**I. INTRODUCTION**
-------------------

1.

This Decision addresses an application initially submitted on 15 December 2021 and briefed on 19 April 2022 and 30 May 2022 by the Kingdom of Spain ("**Spain**" or the "**Applicant**"), asking the *ad hoc* Committee to continue the stay of enforcement of the Award rendered on 17 August 2021 in ICSID Case No. ARB/15/4 between STEAG GmbH ("**STEAG**") and Spain (the "**Award**").

2.

The dispute in the underlying arbitration related to various legislative and regulatory measures implemented by Spain that modified the regulatory and economic regime applicable to producers of electricity from concentrated solar power (*energía termosolar de concentración* or "**CSP**"). STEAG argued that these measures negatively impacted its investment in Arenales Solar PS, S.L., a Spanish company that owned a project for the construction and operation of a solar energy production facility located in Sevilla. The dispute was brought under the Energy Charter Treaty, which entered into force on 16 April 1998 with respect to Germany, and the Kingdom of Spain (the "**ECT**"). STEAG alleged that Spain (i) breached its obligations under Article 13 of the ECT by means of the indirect expropriation of their investment; and (ii) failed to comply with the following obligations under Article 10(1) of the ECT: (a) fair and equitable treatment, (b) most constant protection and security, and (c) umbrella clause. It sought damages in the amount of at least EUR 79 million by way of compensation for the alleged breaches of the ECT, plus costs. In turn, Spain objected to the Tribunal's jurisdiction on the basis of (i) the intra-EU nature of the dispute; (ii) lack of jurisdiction *ratione temporis*; and (iii) Article 21 of the ECT with respect to the claim under Article 10(1) of the ECT: (a)rising out of the Tax on the Value of Production of Electric Power ("**TVPEE**").1 Spain also challenged the admissibility of the expropriation claim under Article 13 of the ECT arising out of the introduction of the TVPEE. It also argued that in any event, no breach of the ECT had taken place, and that STEAG had no right to compensation and ought to bear the costs of the proceedings as well as Spain's legal costs.

"*Impuesto sobre el Valor de la Producción de la Energía Eléctrica*" ("***IVPEE***").

3.

In its Decision on Jurisdiction, Liability and Instructions on the Quantification of Damages of 8 October 2020, the Tribunal decided:

*1) Unanimously to declare that it lacks jurisdiction to hear the dispute regarding the alleged violation of Article 10(1) of the ECT arising out of the introduction of the TVPEE.*

*2) Unanimously to declare inadmissible the claim related to the alleged violation of Article 13 of the ECT arising out of the introduction of the TVPEE.*

*3) Unanimously to reject all other jurisdictional objections of the Respondent.*
